column353: fixed an issue where the events method would time out unexpectedly if no data was sent by the engine for a given amount of time.
column354: the client now sends tcp upgrade headers to hint potential proxies about connection hijacking.
column355: fixed an issue where the auto_remove parameter in dockerclient.containers.run was not taken into account.
column356: several test improvements and cleanup that should make the suite easier to expand and maintain moving forward.
column357: added support for unspecified transfer protocol in base_url when tls is enabled.
column358: added support for custom http headers in docker config file.
column359: added support for the platform parameter in apiclient.build, dockerclient.images.build, apiclient.pull and dockerclient.images.pull
column360: added support for privileged param in client.exec_create
column362: endpoint_config in apiclient.create_service and apiclient.update_service is now endpoint_spec
column363: fixed an issue where early http errors weren t handled properly in streaming responses.
column364: fixed a bug where some environment values in create_container containing unicode characters would raise an encoding error.
column365: fixed an issue where identity tokens in configuration files weren t handled by the library.
column366: fixed a bug with client.push when using api version < 1.5
column367: added support for url paths in the docker host url
column368: fixed a bug where build contexts containing directory symlinks would produce invalid tar archives
column369: added support for the ulimit param in host config.
column370: added support for auto_remove and storage_opt in apiclient.create_host_config and dockerclient.containers.run
column371: added a high-level, user-focused api as docker.dockerclient. see the readme and documentation for more information.
column372: added support for network_mode parameter in start
column373: fixed a bug where client.port would fail if provided with a port of type number
column374: fixed a bug with adapter lookup when using the unix socket adapter
column375: extra_hosts parameter in host config can now also be provided as a list.
column376: fixed issues with handling of double-wildcard ** patterns in .dockerignore files
column377: added support for the tail param in logs.
column379: fixed a bug where using the npipe protocol would sometimes break with valueerror: buffer size must be strictly positive.
column380: added a makefile for running tests in docker
column381: added support for decode in client.build
column382: fixed a bug in client.start where legacy notation for volumes wasn t supported anymore.
column383: added support for consistency, tmpfs_size and tmpfs_mode when creating mount objects.
column384: the client s base_url now tolerates trailing slashes.
column385: added support for remote url builds
column386: there is now a single source of truth for the docker-py version number.
column387: added support for the docker credentials store.
column388: client.push and client.pull will now raise exceptions if the http status indicates an error.
column389: fixed a bug where sockets were closed immediately when attaching over tls.
column390: container.exec_run now returns a tuple of instead of just the output.
column392: fixed an issue where builds would raise a valueerror when attempting to build with a dockerfile on a different windows drive.
column393: dockerclient.swarm.init and apiclient.init_swarm now support the data_path_addr parameter
column394: added git@ to the list of valid prefixes for remote build paths.
column395: added support for prune_builds in apiclient and dockerclient.images
column396: added cpu_rt_runtime and cpu_rt_period as parameters to apiclient.create_host_config and dockerclient.containers.run.
column397: users can now specify a publish mode for ports in endpointspec using the {published_port: } syntax.
column398: fixed a bug where constraints in a tasktemplate object wouldn t be properly converted for the engine.
column399: added support for api connection through unix socket
column400: fixed an issue where the http timeout on streaming responses would sometimes be set incorrectly.
column401: added support for options in ipamconfig
column402: fixed attaching when connecting to the daemon over a unix socket.
column403: fixed a bug where tcp hosts would fail to connect to tls-enabled endpoints
column404: added support for dns_search parameter in start
column405: fixed an issue where providing a dictionary for env in containerspec would provoke an apierror when sent to the engine.
column406: added the upgrade method to the plugin class
column407: all methods that expected a container id as argument now also support a dict containing an id key.
column408: added support for the log_config param in host config.
column409: image.tag now properly returns true when the operation is successful.
column410: fixed a bug where providing an explicit protocol in client.port would fail to yield the expected result.
column412: fixed a bug where broken symlinks inside a build context would cause the build to fail
column413: added support for ipv6 docker host addresses in the client constructor.
column414: set default api version to auto
column415: set a different default number for ssh pools
column416: added support for arbitrary log drivers
column417: resource objects generated by the dockerclient are now hashable.
column418: added support for volumes_from and dns parameters in start. as of api version >= 1.10, these parameters no longer belong to create_container
column419: switched to a better supported backport of the match_hostname function, fixing dependency issues in some environments.
column420: added support for the rm parameter in client.build
column421: added a healthcheck class to docker.types to be used in create_container.
column422: fixed a bug where the cpuset_cpus parameter would not be properly set in apiclient.create_host_config.
column423: build methods can now handle dockerfiles supplied outside of the build context.
column424: fixed a bug where calling network.containers would crash when no containers were associated with the network.
column426: fixed a bug in client.build where the tag parameter would not be taken into account
column427: as a result, urls that don t specify a port are now invalid
column428: fixed a bug where decoding a result stream using the decode parameter would break when using python 3.x
column429: fixed a bug where client.pull and client.push couldn t handle image names containing a dot.
column430: added swarm mode and service management methods. see the documentation for details.
column431: added experimental support for windows named pipes .
column432: added support for a configurable chunk_size parameter in export, get_archive and get_image
column433: added support for global request timeout
column434: added support for the configs api:
column435: fixed a bug where streaming responses were unreliable
column436: fixed a bug where using an integer as the user param in client.create_container would result in a failure.
column437: added support for isolation in hostconfig.
column438: added support for labels in client.create_volume.
column439: added support for the docker_config environment variable when looking up auth config
column440: fixed a bug in client.port where absence of a certain key in the container s json would raise an error
column441: fix base_url to keep tcp protocol on utils.py by letting the responsibility of changing the protocol to parse_host afterwards, letting base_url with the original value.
column443: the updateconfig constructor now allows rollback as a valid value for failure_action
column444: the apiclient and dockerclient constructors now accept a credstore_env parameter. when set, values in this dictionary are added to the environment when executing the credential store process.
column445: added docker.from_env shortcut function. instantiates a client with kwargs_from_env
column447: fixed a bug where auth information would not be properly passed to the engine during a build if the client used a credentials store.
column448: fixed a bug where unix socket connections weren t properly cleaned up, causing resourcewarnings to appear in some cases.
column449: fixed a bug where some environment variables specified through create_container would be improperly formatted
column450: added support for link_local_ips in create_endpoint_config.
column451: fixed a bug where empty chunks in streams was misinterpreted as eof.
column452: the default ssl protocol is now the highest tls v1.x
column453: client.remove_container now raises an exception when trying to remove a running container
column454: fixed a bug where some output wouldn t be streamed properly in streaming chunked responses
column455: fixed a bug that caused attempts to read a data stream over an unsecured tcp socket to crash on windows clients
column456: fixed an issue that caused the client to fail to reach api endpoints when the provided base_url had a trailing slash.
column457: use hostname, username, port and proxycommand settings from .ssh/config when on ssh
column458: the history command now returns a dict instead of a raw json string.
column459: add an alternative ssh connection to the paramiko one, based on shelling out to the ssh client. similar to the behaviour of docker cli
column460: added support for size parameter in containers
column461: fixed a bug where the check_resource decorator would break with some argument-passing methods.
column462: the latter returns an instance of the new registrydata class
column463: fix containers and images documentation examples
column464: fixed a bug where auth would break with python 3
column466: update port_spec regex to allow square brackets for ipv6 addresses
column467: added since, until and filters params to client.events.
column468: added support for container resource limits in client.build.
column469: implemented first version of the builder client
column470: added the use_config_proxy parameter to the following methods: apiclient.build, apiclient.create_container, dockerclient.images.build and dockerclient.containers.run . this parameter will become true by default in the 4.0.0 release.
column471: added support for custom user agent setting in the client constructor. by default, docker-py now also declares itself in the user-agent header.
column472: fixed an issue where the ssl connection adapter would receive an invalid argument.
column473: fixed a bug where the id member on swarm objects wasn t being populated.
column474: added support for the plugins api:
column475: fixed a bug where sockets would close unexpectedly using python 3.x
column476: fixed a bug in streaming methods with python 3
column477: client.pull, client.push and client.build can be streamed now
column478: remove ld_library_path and ssl_cert_file environment variables when shelling out to the ssh client
column479: fixed an issue with client.build streamed logs in python 3
column480: the following parameters have been renamed:
column481: fixed an issue where service.scale would not properly update the service s mode, causing the operation to fail silently
column482: fixed a bug where client.build would try to close context when externally provided
column483: fixed a bug with streaming responses in python 3
column484: when using api version 1.23 or above, load_image will now return a generator of progress as json dicts.
column485: fixed a bug where dockerclient.secrets was not accessible as a property.
column486: fixed a bug in pull where the repo:tag notation wasn t interpreted properly
column487: fixed a bug that caused costly dns lookups on mac osx when connecting to the engine through unix socket
column489: added support for block io constraints in client.create_host_config. this includes parameters blkio_weight, blkio_weight_device, device_read_bps, device_write_bps, device_read_iops and device_write_iops.

column494: logs can now be streamed using the stream parameter.

column497: added support for the pull parameter in client.build
column498: it is now possible to run the docker-py test suite on windows.
column499: added support for volume_driver in client.create_container
column500: added support for custom .dockercfg loading in client.login
column501: in service.update, when the force_update parameter is set to true, the current force_update counter is incremented by one in the update request.

column503: added support for the archive api endpoint .
column504: added support for the cpu cfs parameters in create_host_config.
column505: added support for the forcerm parameter in client.build

column510: added support for the check_duplicate param in client.create_network

column601: fixed a bug where loading a valid docker configuration file would fail

column607: fixed a bug where setting replicas to zero in servicemode would not register as a valid entry.

column2: cupy.sparse module has been deprecated and will be removed in future releases. use cupyx.scipy.sparse instead.
column3: cupy official docker images are now updated to use cuda 8.0 and cudnn 6.0. this change was introduced because cuda 7.5 does not support nvidia pascal gpus.
column4: dtype argument of cupy.ndarray.min and cupy.ndarray.max has been removed to align with the numpy specification.
column5: prior to cupy v4, memory pool was only enabled by default when cupy is used with chainer. in cupy v4, memory pool is now enabled by default, even when you use cupy without chainer. the memory pool significantly improves the performance by mitigating the overhead of memory allocation and cpu/gpu synchronization.
column6: cupy official docker images are now updated to use cuda 9.2 and cudnn 7.
column7: prior to cupy v6, ld_library_path environment variable can be used to override cudnn / nccl libraries bundled in the binary distribution . in cupy v6, ld_library_path will be ignored during discovery of cudnn / nccl; cupy binary distributions always use libraries that comes with the package to avoid errors caused by unexpected override.
column8: starting from cupy v7, python 2.7 and 3.4 are no longer supported as it reaches its end-of-life in january 2020 and march 2019 . python 3.5.1 is the minimum python version supported by cupy v7. please upgrade the python version if you are using affected versions of python to any later versions listed under installation.
column9: for this rule, cupy.scatter_add has been moved to cupyx.scatter_add. cupy.scatter_add is still available as an alias, but it is encouraged to use cupyx.scatter_add instead.
column10: cupy official docker images are now updated to use cuda 11.2 and python 3.8.
column11: the version number has been bumped from v2 to v4 to align with the versioning of chainer. therefore, cupy v3 does not exist.
column12: cupyx namespace has been introduced to provide features specific to cupy while avoiding collision in future. see cupy-specific functions for the list of such functions.
column13: this is a list of changes introduced in each release that users should be aware of when migrating from older versions.
column14: nccl and cudnn no longer included in wheels
column15: nccl and cudnn shared libraires are no longer included in wheels . you can manually install them after installing wheel if you don t have a previous installation; see installation for details.
column16: cupy official docker images are now updated to use cuda 10.2 and python 3.6.
column17: cupyx.scipy namespace has been introduced to provide cuda-enabled scipy functions. cupy.sparse module has been renamed to cupyx.scipy.sparse; cupy.sparse will be kept as an alias for backward compatibility.
column18: cupy v4 now requires nvidia gpu with compute capability 3.0 or larger. see the list of cuda gpus to check if your gpu supports compute capability 3.0.
column19: dropping support of python 2.7 and 3.4
column20: dropped support for cuda 7.0 / 7.5
column21: dropping support of cuda 8.0 and 9.1
column22: cub support and compiler requirement
column23: cub module is now built by default. you can enable the use of cub by setting cupy_accelerators="cub" .
column24: due to this change, g++-6 or later is required when building cupy from the source. see installation for details.
column25: dropping support of cudnn v7.5 and nccl v2.3
column26: copyright 2015, preferred networks, inc. and preferred infrastructure, inc..
column27: when you monitor gpu memory usage , you may notice that gpu memory not being freed even after the array instance become out of scope. this is expected behavior, as the default memory pool caches the allocated memory blocks.
column28: as cuda stream is fully supported in cupy v4, cupy.cuda.randomstate.set_stream, the function to change the stream used by the random number generator, has been removed. please use cupy.cuda.stream.use instead.
column29: # even if the array goes out of scope, its memory block is kept in the pool.
column30: cub_path: no longer required as cupy uses either the cub source bundled with cuda or the one in the cupy distribution.
column31: cupy.rawmodule now delays the compilation to the time of the first call to align the behavior with cupy.rawkernel.
column32: to access the default memory pool instance, use get_default_memory_pool and get_default_pinned_memory_pool. you can access the statistics and free all unused memory blocks cached in the memory pool.
column33: dropping support of cuda 9.0
column34: python 3.5 is no longer supported in cupy v9.
column35: for performance reasons, cupy.count_nonzero has been changed to return zero-dimensional ndarray instead of int when axis=none. see the discussion in #154 for more details.
column36: scipy and optuna are now pre-installed.
column37: cuda 9.0 is no longer supported. use cuda 9.2 or later.
column38: cupy.scatter_add, which was deprecated in cupy v4, has been removed. use cupyx.scatter_add instead.
column39: # for performance, the size of actual allocation may become larger than the requested array size.
column40: to use these images, you may need to upgrade the nvidia driver on your host. see requirements of nvidia-docker for details.
column41: to use these images, you may need to upgrade the nvidia driver on your host. see requirements of nvidia-docker for details.
column42: cupy.allclose now returns the result as 0-dim gpu array instead of python bool to avoid device synchronization.
column43: dropping support of numpy 1.16 and scipy 1.3
column44: update of docker images
column45: update of docker images
column46: update of docker images
column47: update of docker images
column48: cuda 8.0 and 9.1 are no longer supported. use cuda 9.0, 9.2, 10.0, or later.
column49: api changes
column50: you can even disable the default memory pool by the code below. be sure to do this before any other cupy operations.
column51: binary packages ignore ld_library_path
column52: created using sphinx 3.5.4.
column53: changed behavior of count_nonzero function

column2: features and limitations
column3: the line and column parameters of jedi.script are now deprecated
column4: the import logic has been rewritten to look more like python s. there is now an inferstate.modules import cache, which resembles sys.modules.
column5: a new and better parser for parsing diffs of python code.
column6: project attributes are now read accessible
column7: stubs are used now for type inference
column8: python 2 support deprecated. for this release it is best effort. python 2 has reached the end of its life and now it s just about a smooth transition. bugs for python 2 will not be fixed anymore and a third of the tests are already skipped.
column9: memory consumption for compiled modules has been reduced drastically. loading times are down as well .
column10: fixed an issue with embedded python, see link
column11: typeshed is used for better type inference
column12: removed settings.no_completion_duplicates. it wasn t tested and nobody was probably using it anyway.
column13: started using annotations
column14: add fuzzy completions with script.completions
column15: better usages - a lot of internal code was ripped out and improved.
column16: this is likely going to be the last minor version that supports python 2 and python3.5. bugfixes will be provided in 0.17.1+. the next minor/major version will probably be jedi 1.0.0.
column17: prepared the parser to be factored out of jedi.
column18: functions with @property now return property instead of function in name.type
column19: added get_line_code to name and completion objects.
column20: much faster parser with builtin part caching.
column21: the api documentation is now way more readable and complete. check it out under link a lot of it has been rewritten.
column22: added support for refactoring. the following refactorings have been implemented: script.rename, script.inline, script.extract_variable and script.extract_function.
column23: small bugfix and removal of a print statement
column24: integrated the parser of 2to3. this will make refactoring possible. it will also be possible to check for error messages in the future.
column25: understand async/await and autocomplete it
column26: signatures are now detected a lot better
column27: added code search capabilities both for individual files and projects. the new functions are project.search, project.complete_search, script.search and script.complete_search.
column28: installation and configuration
column29: tensorflow, numpy and pandas completions should now be about 4-10x faster after the first time they are used.
column30: repl completion is starting to become usable.
column31: with the new parser, the type inference also completely changed. it s now simpler and more readable.
column32: removed settings.use_filesystem_cache and settings.additional_dynamic_modules, they have no usage anymore. pretty much nobody was probably using them.
column33: this will be the last release that supports python 2 and python 3.5. 0.18.0 will be python 3.6+.
column34: various small api changes. generally this release focuses on stability and refactoring of internal apis.
column35: reworked name.full_name, should have more correct return values
column36: added autocompletion support for namespace packages.
column37: added script.help to make it easier to display a help window to people. now returns pydoc information as well for python keywords/operators. this means that on the class keyword it will now return the docstring of python s builtin function help.
column38: *args/**kwargs resolving. if possible jedi replaces the parameters with the actual alternatives.
column39: added an interpreter class to the api to make autocompletion in repl possible.
column40: default environments are now using the same python version as the python process. in 0.12.x, we used to load the latest python version on the system.
column41: this is likely going to be the last minor release before 1.0.
column42: cannot crash with segfaults anymore
column43: parso update - the caching layer was broken
column44: completions deprecated, use complete instead
column45: files bigger than one mb get cropped to avoid getting stuck completely.
column46: add follow_imports to name.goto. now its signature matches script.goto.
column47: implict namespaces are now a separate types in name.type
column48: split jedi s parser into a separate project called parso.
column49: bugfix release, the last release forgot to include files that improve autocompletion for builtin libraries. fixed.
column50: introducing operator precedence, which makes calculating correct array indices and __getattr__ strings possible.
column51: this release forces you to upgrade parso. if you don t, nothing will work anymore. otherwise changes should be limited to bug fixes. unfortunately jedi still uses a few internals of parso that make it hard to keep compatibility over multiple releases. parso >=0.3.0 is going to be needed.
column52: goto on a function/attribute in a class now goes to the definition in its super class.
column53: added project support. this allows a user to specify which folders jedi should work with.
column54: dropped python 2 and python 3.5
column55: usages deprecated, use get_references instead
column56: remove python 3.3 support. python 3.3 support has been dropped by the python foundation.
column57: callsignature.index should now be working a lot better
column58: better support for the walrus operator
column59: python packaging sucks. some files were not included in 0.10.1.
column60: edit on github
column61: cleaned up import logic
column62: fixed a few very annoying bugs.
column63: removed python 3.4 support
column64: switched from lgpl to mit license.
column65: when using interpreter, properties are now executed, since a lot of people have complained about this. discussion in #1299, #1347.
column66: added script.get_syntax_errors to display syntax errors in the current script.
column67: added an option to pass environment variables to environment

column2: you can now use strike-through in markdown with ~~text~~, and the corresponding html tags for strike-through, quotes and underlined text.
column3: markdown and html parsing now behave correctly with leading whitespace.
column4: __all__ is now defined, so from telethon import * imports sane defaults . this is however discouraged and should be used only in quick scripts.
column5: other internal changes include a somewhat more readable .to_bytes function and pre-computing the flag instead using bit shifting. the tlobject.constructor_id has been renamed to tlobject.constructor_id, and .subclass_of_id is also uppercase now.
column6: besides this. tlobject.stringify was showing bytes as lists and rpc errors are reported by default:
column7: archiving dialogs with dialog.archive or client.edit_folder is now possible.
column8: database is now upgraded if the version was lower, not different. from now on, this should help with upgrades and downgrades slightly.
column9: working with chats and channels
column10: files meant to be ran by the user now use shebangs and proper permissions.
column11: this update prepares the library for catching up with updates with the new telethon.telegram_client.telegramclient.catch_up method. this feature needs more testing, but for now it will let you catch up on some old updates that occurred while the library was offline, and brings some new features and bug fixes.
column12: not using async with when needed is now a proper error.
column13: some ids start with 1000 and these would be wrongly treated as channels.
column14: the library uses again only a single connection. less updates are be dropped now, and the performance is even better than using temporary connections.
column15: spotted a new place where brokenauthkeyerror would be raised, and it now is raised there.
column16: the above point means reply_message is now .get_reply_message, and fwd_from_entity is now get_fwd_sender. also forward was gone in the previous version, and you should be using fwd_from instead.
column17: reconnection occurs at the mtprotosender level, and receiving responses follows a similar process, but now asyncio.future is used for the results which are no longer part of all tlobject, instead are part of the tlmessage which simplifies things.
column18: pathlib.path is now supported for downloading and uploading media.
column19: yet again, a lot of work has been put into reworking the low level connection classes. this means asyncio.open_connection is now used correctly and the errors it can produce are handled properly. the separation between packing, encrypting and network is now abstracted away properly, so reasoning about the code is easier, making it more maintainable.
column20: answering inline queries with a photo or document will now send the photo or document used in the resulting message by default. not sending the media was technically a bug, but some people may be relying on this old behaviour. you can use the old behaviour with include_media=false.
column21: hopefully a very ungrateful bug has been removed. when you used to invoke some request through update handlers, it could potentially enter an infinite loop. this has been mitigated and it s now safe to invoke things again! a lot of updates were being dropped , and this has been fixed too.
column22: dialog.delete has existed for a while, and now client.delete_dialog exists too so you can easily leave chats or delete dialogs without fetching all dialogs.
column23: message.from_id is now a peer, not int! if you want the marked sender id , replace all uses of .from_id with .sender_id. this will mostly work, but of course in old and new versions you have to account for the fact that this sender may no longer be a user.
column24: client.disconnect is now asynchronous again. this means you need to await it. you don t need to worry about this if you were using with client or client.run_until_disconnected. this should prevent the pending task was destroyed errors.
column25: besides the obvious layer change, the loop argument is now ignored. it has been deprecated since python 3.8 and will be removed in python 3.10, and also caused some annoying warning messages when using certain parts of the library. if you were relying on using a different loop from the one that was set, things may break.
column26: if the python-socks library is installed , it will be used instead of pysocks for proxy support. this should fix some issues with proxy timeouts, because the new library natively supports asyncio.
column27: asynchronous file descriptors are now allowed during download and upload.
column28: however, that doesn t mean calls are not possible with telethon. if you want to help design a python library to perform audio calls, which can then be used with telethon , please refer to @pytgcallschat and join the relevant chat to discuss and help with the implementation!
column29: for proxy users, a pull request was merged that will use the python-socks library when available for proxy support. this library natively supports asyncio, so it should work better than the old pysocks. pysocks will still be used if the new library is not available, and both will be handled transparently by telethon so you don t need to worry about it.
column30: client.send_voice_note is now client.send_file with is_voice=true.
column31: .name property is now properly supported when sending and downloading files.
column32: the reason to bring this up is that telegram has changed things again, and with the introduction of anonymous administrators and channel comments, the sender of a message may not be a user! to accomodate for this, the field is now a peer and not int. as a reminder, it s always a good idea to use telethon s friendly methods and custom properties, which have a higher stability guarantee than accessing raw api fields.
column33: client.get_dialogs is only called once again when an entity is not found to avoid flood waits.
column34: of course there was more work to be done regarding updates, and it s here! the library comes with a new events module . this are pretty much all the additions that come with this version change, but they are a nice addition. refer to to get started with events.
column35: two new event handlers to ease creating normal bots with the library, namely events.inlinequery and events.callbackquery for handling @inlinebot queries or reacting to a button click. for this second option, there is an even better way:
column36: this version is again compatible with python 3.x versions below 3.5 .
column37: on a different order of things, .connect also features a timeout. notice that the timeout= is not passed as a parameter anymore, and is instead specified when creating the telegramclient.
column38: bug fixes and new small features
column39: bug fixes and new small features
column40: bug fixes and new small features
column41: support for inline mentions when sending and editing messages. they work like inline urls ) and also support the bot-api style .
column42: request will be retried up to 5 times by default rather than failing on the first attempt.
column43: methods with a lot of arguments can no longer be used without specifying their argument. instead you need to use named arguments. this improves readability and not needing to learn the order of the arguments, which can also change.
column44: internally, the .to_bytes function has been replaced with __bytes__ so now you can do bytes.
column45: view new and changed raw api methods.
column46: view new and changed raw api methods.
column47: for those who aren t able to install cryptg, the support for libssl has been added back. while interfacing libssl is not as fast, the speed when downloading and sending files should really be noticeably faster.
column48: requests larger than 512 bytes will be compressed through gzip, and if the result is smaller, this will be uploaded instead.
column49: the session s have been revisited thanks to the work of @tulir and they now use an abc so you can easily implement your own!
column50: code is now more pythonic , and other internal improvements , such as using logger instead a bare print too.
column51: there probably are some bugs left, which haven t yet been found. however, the majority of code works and the application is already usable! not only that, but also uses the latest scheme as of now and handles way better the errors. this tag is being used to mark this release as stable enough.
column52: new connections used to be cached and then reused. now only their sessions are saved, as temporary connections are spawned only when needed.
column53: events.chataction now has respond, reply and delete for the message that triggered it.
column54: reworked readme and examples at link
column55: underscores have been renamed from filenames. this means telethon.errors.rpc_error_list won t work, but you should have been using telethon.errors all this time instead.
column56: inlinebuilder only worked with local files, but files from anywhere are supported.
column57: empty except are no longer used which means sending a keyboard interrupt should now work properly.
column58: report_errors has been removed since it s currently not used, and flood_sleep_threshold is now part of the client.
column59: msgsack is now sent in a container rather than its own request.
column60: the thumb for download_media now supports both str and videosize.
column61: error descriptions and information about methods is now loaded from a csv file instead of being part of several messy json files.
column62: hope the new, super simple readme.rst encourages people to use telethon and make it better with either suggestions, or pull request. pull requests are super appreciated, but showing some support by leaving a star also feels nice .
column63: received errors are acknowledged to the server, so they don t happen over and over.
column64: the list of known peers could end corrupted and have users with access_hash=none, resulting in struct error for it not being an integer. you shouldn t encounter this issue anymore.
column65: this version also updates the format of sqlite sessions , so after upgrading and using an old session, the session will be updated, which means trying to use it back in older versions of the library won t work.
column66: the release is primarily intended to test this big change, but also fixes python 3.5.2 compatibility which was broken due to a trailing comma.
column67: .create_new_connection is gone for good. no need to deal with this manually since new connections are now handled on demand by the library itself.
column68: invite links will now use cache, so using them as entities is cheaper.
column69: this is not considered a breaking change because stderr should only be used for logging purposes, not to emit information others may consume .
column70: now you can use python s pickle module to serialize rpcerror and any other tlobject thanks to @vegeta1k95! a fix that was fairly simple, but still might be useful for many people.
column71: timeouterror is now ignored, since the request will be retried up to 5 times by default.
column72: get_input_* now works with vectors
column73: get_input_* now works with vectors
column74: get_input_* now works with vectors
column75: this will install any version compatible with the written version . patch releases will never break your code . you can also use that syntax in pip install. your code can t know what new versions will look like, so saying it will work with all versions is a lie and will cause issues.
column76: .reconnect behavior has been changed to also be more consistent by making the assumption that we ll only reconnect if the server has disconnected us, and is now private.
column77: for convenience, a new object.to_json has been added which will by default format both of those problematic types into something sensible.
column78: some bug in python 3.5.2 s asyncio causing 100% cpu load if you forgot to call client.disconnect. the method is called for you on object destruction, but you still should disconnect manually or use a with block.
column79: the last release added support to force_file on any media, including things that were not possible before like .webp files. however, the force_document toggle commonly used for photos was applied twice , which prevented telegram for analyzing the images. long story short, sending files to the stickers bot stopped working, but that s been fixed now, and sending photos as documents include the size attribute again as long as telegram adds it.
column80: the flow for sending a request is as follows: the telegramclient creates a mtprotosender with a connection, and the sender starts send and receive loops. sending a request means enqueueing it in the sender, which will eventually pack and encrypt it with its connectionstate instead of using the entire session instance. when the data is packed, it will be sent over the connection and ultimately over the tcpclient.
column81: internally, the generated code now resides under a lot less files, simply for the sake of avoiding so many unnecessary files. the generated code is not meant to be read by anyone, simply to do its job.
column82: the interactivetelegramclient is not shipped with pip anymore.
column83: type hinting for all the generated request s and tlobjects! ides like pycharm will benefit from this.
column84: different default limit for iter_messages and get_messages.
column85: server-side changes caused clicking on inline buttons to trigger a different error, which is now handled correctly.
column86: more bug fixes include a correct parsing of certain tlobjects thanks to @stek29, and some wrong calls that would cause the library to crash thanks to @andr-04, and the readthread not re-starting if you were already authorized.
column87: it has been a while since the last release, and a few bug fixes have been made since then. this release includes them and updates the scheme layer.
column88: code generation was using f-strings, which are only supported on python 3.6.
column89: invoking multiple requests at once with ordered=true was deadlocking.
column90: mostly bug fixes, but now there is a new parameter on client.iter_messages to support reversing the order in which messages are returned.
column91: new formatting_entities parameter in client.send_message, and client.send_file to bypass the parse mode and manually specify the formatting entities.
column92: rpc errors without parent requests caused a crash, and better logging.
column93: signing in required a named code= parameter, but usage without a name was really widespread so it has been reverted.
column94: add_mark= is now back on utils.get_input_peer and also on client.get_input_entity.
column95: the correct amount of random bytes is now used in dh request
column96: the updatesthread is now a daemon, and should cause less issues.
column97: with client:
column98: old usernames are evicted from cache, so getting entities by cached username should now be more reliable.
column99: dead connections are now detected instead entering an infinite loop.
column100: setup.py used to fail with wrongly generated code.
column101: error reporting is done in the background, and has a shorter timeout.
column102: downloading media on different data centers is now up to x2 faster, since there used to be an invaliddcerror for each file part tried to be downloaded.
column103: automatic reconnection with no retries was failing.
column104: changing the ip to which you connect to is as simple as client.session.server_address = 'ip', since now the server address is always queried from the session.
column105: the tlobject s have now acquired a new .resolve method. while this should be used by the library alone , it means that you can now use peer types or even usernames where a inputpeer is required. the object now has access to the client, so that it can fetch the right type if needed, or access the session database. furthermore, you can reuse requests that need autocast , since .resolve is called when invoking. before, it was only done on object construction.
column106: the telethon_generator/ can now convert .tl files into .json, mostly as a proof of concept, but it might be useful for other people.
column107: duplicated updates should now be ignored.
column108: with the layer 103, telethon is now able to send and receive animated stickers! these use the 'application/x-tgsticker' mime-type and for now, you can access its raw data, which is a gzipped json.
column109: unused attributes have been removed from the tlobject class too, and .sign_up returns the user that just logged in in a similar way to .sign_in now.
column110: answering inline queries with media no works properly. you can now use the library to create inline bots and send stickers through them!
column111: the reason for this change is as simple as reading and writing shouldn t be related . even when you re simply ignoring updates, this way, once you send a request you will only need to read the result for the request. whatever telegram sent before has already been read and outside the buffer.
column112: several new examples and updated documentation.
column113: .get_input_photo is now used in the generated code.
column114: this version handles updates in a different thread . this means that both the low level tcpclient and the not-so-low-level mtprotosender are now multi-thread safe, so you can use them with more than a single thread without worrying!
column115: telegramclient.get_entity is now public, and uses the @lru_cache decorator.
column116: bug fixes and enhancements
column117: bug fixes and enhancements
column118: bug fixes and enhancements
column119: you may have noticed that the patch versions between v1.7.2 to v1.7.7 have not been documented. this is because patch versions should only contain bug fixes, no new features or breaking changes. this hasn t been the case in the past, but from now on, the library will try to adhere more strictly to the semantic versioning principles.
column120: and even the following will hopefully work:
column121: telethon.tl.custom.dialog.dialog instances can now be casted into inputpeer.
column122: sleeping on the main thread is not done anymore. you will have to except floodwaiterror s.
column123: .get_message_history also returns a single list instead a tuple, with the message instances modified to make them more convenient.
column124: .parse_username would fail with www. or a trailing slash.
column125: a new, more lightweight class has been added. the telegrambareclient is now the base of the normal telegramclient, and has the most basic features.
column126: bot-api-style file_id can now be used to send files and download media. you can also access telethon.utils.resolve_bot_file_id and telethon.utils.pack_bot_file_id to resolve and create these file ids yourself. note that each user has its own id for each file so you can t use a bot s file_id with your user, except stickers.
column127: the method reference now shows which methods can be used if you sign in with a bot_token.
column128: telegram is more than an application to send and receive messages. you can also send and receive media. now, this implementation also gives you the power to upload and download media from any message that contains it! nothing can now stop you from filling up all your disk space with all the photos! if you want to, of course.
column129: the library has been around for well over a year. a lot of improvements have been made, a lot of user complaints have been fixed, and a lot of user desires have been implemented. it s time to consider the public api as stable, and remove some of the old methods that were around until now for compatibility reasons. but there s one more surprise!
column130: working with different data centers finally works! on a different order of things, reconnection is now performed automatically every time telegram decides to kick us off their servers, so now telethon can really run forever and ever! in theory.
column131: .sender is the .chat when the message is sent in a broadcast channel. this makes sense, because the sender of the message was the channel itself, but you now must take into consideration that it may be either a user or channel instead of being none.
column132: fix sending albums with client.send_file was not returning the sent messages.
column133: version v0.14 had started working on the new .to_bytes method to dump the binarywriter and its usage on the .on_send when serializing tlobjects, and this release finally removes it. the speed up when serializing things to bytes should now be over twice as fast wherever it s needed.
column134: crashing when migrating to a new layer and receiving old updates should not happen now.
column135: the purpose of this release is to denote a big change, now you can connect to telegram through different **connection modes**. also, a second thread will always be started when you connect a telegramclient, despite whether you ll be handling updates or ignoring them, whose sole purpose is to constantly read from the network.
column136: no second thread is spawned unless one or more update handlers are added.
column137: markdown parsing is not part of telethon itself anymore, although there are plans to support it again through a some external module.
column138: downloading to file=bytes will now return a bytes object with the downloaded media.
column139: utils.resolve_id was misbehaving with some identifiers.
column140: first things first, sorry for updating the layer in the previous patch version. that should only be done between major versions ideally, but due to how telegram works, it s done between minor versions. however raw api has and will always be considered unsafe , this meaning that you should always use the convenience client methods instead. these methods don t cover the full api yet, so pull requests are welcome.
column141: telethon s focus is being an asyncio-based, pure-python implementation to interact with telegram s api. streaming audio is beyond the current scope of the project and would be a big undertaking.
column142: there is a new preferred way to invoke requests, which you re encouraged to use:
column143: besides this, every telegram object now features a new default .__str__ look, and also a .stringify method to pretty format them, if you ever need to inspect them.
column144: when downloading media, the right sender is directly used without previously triggering migrate errors.
column145: the service message produced by message.pin is now returned.
column146: the documentation has been updated with a brand new asyncio crash course to encourage you use it. you can still use the threaded version if you want though.
column147: fix some cyclic imports and installing dependencies from the git repository.
column148: downloading files now retries once on timeouterror, which has been happening recently. it is not guaranteed to work, but it should help.
column149: client.pin_message now also works with message objects.
column150: both client.start and client.run_until_disconnected can be ran in both a synchronous way or from an async def where they need to have an await.
column151: telegram decided to update the layer 66 without increasing the number. this has been fixed and now we re up-to-date again.
column152: incoming = outgoing = true was not working properly.
column153: if you relied on internals like the mtprotosender and the telegrambareclient, both are gone. they are now mtprotosender and telegrambaseclient and they behave differently.
column154: : broken due to a condition which should had been the opposite , fixed 4 commits ahead on link
column155: these bug fixes are available in this release and beyond:
column156: also, being able to download and upload media implies that you can do the same with the library itself. did i need to mention that? oh, and now, with even less bugs! i hope.
column157: in some cases, a request that failed to be sent would be forgotten, causing the original caller to be locked forever for a response that would never arrive. failing requests should now consistently be automatically re-sent.
column158: telegram has had group calls for some weeks now. this new version contains the raw api methods needed to initiate and manage these group calls, however, the library will likely not offer ways to stream audio directly.
column159: new method to .create_new_connection, which can be ran in parallel with the original connection. this will return the previously mentioned telegrambareclient already connected.
column160: this version doesn t really bring many new features, but rather focuses on updating the code base to support the latest available telegram layer, 91. this layer brings polls, and you can create and manage them through telethon!
column161: photopathsize is now ignored when determining a download size, since this size is not a jpeg thumbnail unlike the rest.
column162: conversations with custom events failed to be cancelled.
column163: the following are also present in v1.10.10:
column164: the following are also present in v1.10.10:
column165: fixed connecting with connectiontcpobfuscated.
column166: brokenpipeerror was still being raised due to an incorrect order on the try/except block.
column167: the fd is removed from the reader upon closing the socket. this should be noticeable in windows.
column168: libssl will also be used if available on your system . this speed boost should also apply to uploading and downloading files.
column169: upload and download methods are no longer part of telegrambareclient.
column170: .sign_up does not take a phone argument anymore. change this or you will be using phone as code, and it will fail! the definition looks like def sign_up.
column171: some other additions are a tiny fix when handling updates, which was ignoring some of them, nicer __str__ and .stringify methods for the tlobject s, and not stopping the readthread if you try invoking something there .
column172: support for higher limits on .get_history and .get_dialogs.
column173: mtprotosender is not thread-safe, but it doesn t need to be since a new connection will be spawned when needed.
column174: telethon.telegram_client.telegramclient.iter_messages s min_id/max_id was being ignored by telegram. this is now worked around.
column175: the library is now using mtproto 2.0! this shouldn t really affect you as an end user, but at least it means the library will be ready by the time mtproto 1.0 is deprecated.
column176: the threaded version of the library will no longer be maintained, primarily because it never was properly maintained anyway. if you have old code, stick with old versions of the library, such as 0.19.1.6.
column177: for backwards-compatibility sake, the library has introduced the properties message.reply_to_msg_id and message.to_id that behave like they did before .
column178: the background thread will only be started after you re authorized on telegram , and several other attempts at polishing the experience with this thread.
column179: fixed typos and enhanced some documentation in general.
column180: the telethon.network.connection.common.connection class is now an abc, and the old connectionmode is now gone. use a specific connection instead.
column181: the connection instance is only created once now, and reused later.
column182: multiple captions are now supported when sending albums.
column183: some errors and methods are documented a bit clearer.
column184: telegram s terms of service are now accepted when creating a new account. this can possibly help avoid bans. this has no effect for accounts that were created before.
column185: .send_file accepts a new optional thumbnail parameter, and returns the message with the sent file.
column186: with that out of the way, let s list the additions and bug fixes in this release:
column187: this update brings a new way to work with updates, and it s begging for your feedback, or better names or ways to do what you can do now.
column188: some people or chats have a lot of profile photos. you can now iterate over all of them with the new client.iter_profile_photos method.
column189: relative import is now used everywhere, so you can rename telethon to anything else.
column190: the default will still be a sqlitesession, but you might want to use the new alchemysessioncontainer if you need. refer to the section of the documentation on session files for more.
column191: file cache now relies on the hash of the file uploaded instead its path, and is now persistent in the *.session file. report any bugs on this!
column192: if you re one of those who runs telethon for a long time , this update by @strayge will be great for you. it sends periodic pings to the telegram servers so you don t get disconnected and you can still send and receive updates!
column193: more bug fixes and enhancements
column194: more bug fixes and enhancements
column195: more bug fixes and enhancements
column196: using entities with access_hash = 0 will now work in more cases.
column197: this version is a major overhaul of the library internals. the core has been rewritten, cleaned up and refactored to fix some oddities that have been growing inside the library.
column198: iterating over messages in reverse with a date as offset wouldn t work.
column199: .get_input_entity was failing for ids and other cases, also making more requests than it should.
column200: using proxies and https connection mode may now work properly.
column201: sending images as photos that are too large will now be resized before uploading, reducing the time it takes to upload them and also avoiding errors when the image was too large . the images will remain unchanged if you send it as a document.
column202: a silly bug which hadn t been spotted has now been fixed. now you can invoke other requests from within your update callbacks. however this is not advised. you should post these updates to some other thread, and let that thread do the job instead. invoking a request from within a callback will mean that, while this request is being invoked, no other things will be read.
column203: the newest telegram update has a new method to also retrieve megagroup statistics, which can now be used with client.get_stats. this way you ll be able to access the raw data about your channel or megagroup statistics.
column204: fixed some issues with client.kick_participant and client.edit_admin.
column205: client.iter_dialogs will now locally check for the offset date, since telegram ignores it.
column206: fixed sending albums and more within client.conversation.
column207: servererror s will be ignored, and the request will immediately be retried.
column208: the library already had a way to easily convert the objects the api returned into dictionaries through object.to_dict, but some of the fields are dates or bytes which json can t serialize directly.
column209: date was being represented as a float instead of an int.
column210: always read the corresponding tlobject from api responses, except for some special cases still.
column211: events.callbackquery with string regex was not working properly.
column212: the custom.message class has been rewritten in a cleaner way and overall feels less hacky in the library. this should perform better than the previous way in which it was patched.
column213: timedelta is now supported where a date is expected, which means you can e.g. ban someone for timedelta.
column214: auth_key_duplicated is handled automatically on connection.
column215: mostly fixes, and added some new things that can be done in this new layer.
column216: manually using client.sign_up should now work correctly, instead of claiming code invalid .
column217: errors that couldn t be handled on the background thread will be raised on the next call to .invoke or updates.poll.
column218: the same applies to .download_msg_media, which has been renamed to .download_media. the method now supports a message itself too, rather than only message.media. the specialized .download_photo, .download_document and .download_contact still exist, but are private.
column219: new way to work with updates
column220: new way to work with updates
column221: new way to work with updates
column222: fixed some errors and cleaned up the generation of code.
column223: chat and channel participants can now be used as peers.
column224: default to markdown parsing when sending and editing messages.
column225: and yes, you can create more complex button layouts with lists:
column226: this means that the code is easier to understand and reason about, including the code flow such as conditions, exceptions, where to reconnect, how the library should behave, and separating different retry types such as disconnections or call fails, but it also means that some things will necessarily break in this version.
column227: in addition, the library now logs warning or error messages to stderr by default! you no longer should be left wondering why isn t my event handler working if you forgot to configure logging. it took so long for this change to arrive because nobody noticed that telethon was using a logging.nullhandler when it really shouldn t have.
column228: yet another update to fix some bugs and increase the stability of the library, or, at least, that was the attempt!
column229: new client.get_permissions method to query a participant s permissions in a group or channel. this request is slightly expensive in small group chats because it has to fetch the entire chat to check just a user, so use of a cache is advised.
column230: built with sphinx using a theme provided by read the docs.
column231: correctly catch and raise all rpc errors.
column232: new minor version, new layer change! this time is a good one to remind every consumer of python libraries that you should always specify fixed versions of your dependencies! if you re using a requirements.txt file and you want to stick with the old version for the time being, you can use the following syntax:
column233: user joined event was being treated as user was invited .
column234: interactive sign in now supports signing in with a bot token.
column235: telegramclient is now only an abstraction over the telegrambareclient, which can only do basic things, such as invoking requests, working with files, etc. if you don t need any of the abstractions the telegramclient, you can now use the telegrambareclient in a much more comfortable way.
column236: message.edit now respects the previous message buttons or link preview being hidden. if you want to toggle them you need to explicitly set them. this is generally the desired behaviour, but may cause some bots to have buttons when they shouldn t.
column237: updated documentation and list of known errors.
column238: updated documentation and list of known errors.
column239: 2fa code was updated to work under the latest layer.
column240: updates thread is only started after a successful login.
column241: all requests that touch the network are now methods and need to have their await .
column242: you can no longer assign to message.reply_to_msg_id and message.to_id because these are now properties that offer a view to the real value from a different field.
column246: the draft class now exposes .text and .raw_text, as well as a new draft.send to send it.
column247: this version also includes the v1.4.1 hot-fix, which was a single quick fix and didn t really deserve an entry in the changelog.
column248: html parsing thanks to @tulir! it can be used similar to markdown: client.send_message.
column249: client.disconnect is now synchronous, but you can still await it for consistency or compatibility.
column250: raise proxyconnectionerror instead looping forever so you can except it on your own code and behave accordingly.
column251: obj.to_dict now has a '_' key with the type used.
column252: you can use the telegramclient inside of with blocks, which will client.start and disconnect the client for you:
column253: the default parameters used to initialize a connection now match the format of those used by telegram desktop.
column254: the session file is saved less often, which could result in a noticeable speed-up when working with a lot of incoming updates.
column255: the correct chat is now always returned from returned messages.
column256: this also implies that you won t need to send a request to receive an update . they will all be received instantly.
column260: updated documentation and list of known rpc errors.
column261: me/self check for .get_entity has been moved up so if someone has me or self as their name they won t be retrieved.
column262: furthermore, nearly everything has been documented, thus preparing the library for read the docs , and the logging are now better placed.
column263: the auth_key generation has been moved from .connect to .invoke. there were some issues were .connect failed and the auth_key was none so this will ensure to have a valid auth_key when needed, even if brokenauthkeyerror is raised.
column264: in the beginning, session files used to be pickle. this proved to be bad as soon as one wanted to add more fields. for this reason, they were migrated to use json instead. but this proved to be bad as soon as one wanted to save things like entities , so now it properly uses sqlite3, which has been well tested, to save the session files! calling .get_input_entity using a username no longer will need to fetch it first, so it s really 0 calls again. calling .get_entity will always fetch the most up to date version.
column265: the layer changed, and a lot of things did too. if you are using raw api, you should be careful with this. in addition, some attributes weren t of type datetime when they should be, which has been fixed.
column266: if you have worked with flask templates, you will love this update, since it gives you the same features but even more conveniently:
column267: this release has no new major features. however, it contains some small changes that make using telethon a little bit easier. now those who have installed telethon via pip can also take advantage of changes, such as less bugs, creating empty instances of tlobjects, specifying a timeout and more!
column269: new client.set_proxy method which lets you change the proxy without recreating the client. you will need to reconnect for it to take effect, but you won t need to recreate the client. this is also an external contribution.
column270: sending a copy of messages with polls will now work when possible.
column271: without rowid is not used in sqlite anymore.
column272: in addition, all methods in the client now are fully annotated with type hints! more work needs to be done, but this should already help a lot when using telethon from any ides.
column273: avoid crashing on certain terminals by using known ascii characters where possible.
column274: date was being serialized as local date, but that was wrong.
column275: a disconnection is made when retries reached 0 . this hasn t been tested but it might fix the bug.
column276: client.send_file now accepts external http:// and https:// urls.
column277: there isn t an entry for v1.5.4 because it contained only one hot-fix regarding loggers. this update is slightly bigger so it deserves mention.
column278: fixed possibly crashes if trying to .invoke a request while .reconnect was being called on the updatesthread.
column279: new custom func= on all events. these will receive the entire event, and a good usage example is func=lambda e: e.is_private.
column280: once again nothing major, but a few bug fixes and primarily the new layer deserves a new minor release.
column282: the main feature of this release is that telethon now has a custom database for all the entities you encounter, instead depending on @lru_cache on the .get_entity method.
column283: a new sequential_updates parameter when creating the client for updates to be processed sequentially. this is useful when you need to make sure that all updates are processed in order, such as a script that only forwards incoming messages somewhere else.
column284: events now override __str__ and implement .stringify, just like every other tlobject does.
column285: timeouterror was not handled during automatic reconnects.
column286: however, be careful with spamming!! do not use the program for that!
column294: as a user, you shouldn t worry about this, other than being aware that quite a few changes were made in the insides of the library and you should report any issues that you encounter with this version if any.
column295: the pts of incoming updates could be none.
column296: using proper classes for generating authorization keys and to write out tlmessage s.
column297: downloading media from cdns failed due to having forgotten to remove a single line.
column298: before getting any further, here s a quick fix-up with things that should have been on v0.13.5 but were missed. specifically, the timeout when receiving a request will now work properly.
column299: this release primarly focuses on a few bug fixes and enhancements. although more stuff may have broken along the way.
column300: you can send albums larger than 10 items , as well as mixing normal files with photos.
column301: sending a file with client.send_file now works fine when you pass an existing dice media .
column302: avoid crashing with certain invalid utf-8 strings.
column303: the library trusts the server with updates again. the library will not check for duplicates anymore, and when the server kicks us, it will run getstaterequest so the server starts sending updates again . but this update also brings a few more changes!
column304: the telegramclient methods .send_photo_file, .send_document_file and .send_media_file are now a single method called .send_file. it s also important to note that the order of the parameters has been swapped: first to who you want to send it, then the file itself.
column305: new comment_to parameter in client.send_message, and client.send_file to comment on channel posts.
column306: markdown parser s offset uses match.start to allow custom regex.
column307: some filter types were not supported by telethon.telegram_client.telegramclient.iter_participants.
column308: '__' is no longer considered valid in usernames.
column309: anyone who wants to update the documentation for known errors, or whether some methods can be used as a bot, user or both, can now be easily edited. everyone is encouraged to help document this better!
column310: this update brings a few general enhancements that are enough to deserve a new release, with a new feature: beta markdown-like parsing for .send_message!
column311: the thumb was being ignored when sending files from inputfile.
column312: in addition to that, you can now easily load and export session files without creating any on-disk file thanks to the stringsession:
column313: hexadecimal invite links are now supported. you didn t need them, but they will now work.
column314: new raise_last_call_error parameter in the client constructor to raise the same error produced by the last failing call, rather than a generic valueerror.
column315: you can filter events.newmessage by sender id, and also whether they are forwards or not.
column316: you can use a phone number or an username for methods like .send_message, .send_file, and all the other quick-access methods provided by the telegramclient.
column317: downloading photos is broken. this is fixed in v1.7.1.
column318: new retry_delay delay for the client to be used on auto-reconnection.
column319: new way to handle the result of requests. the old valueerror the previously sent request must be resent. however, no request was previously sent . should not happen anymore.
column320: html parsing was failing due to not handling surrogates properly.
column321: invoke other requests from within update callbacks
column322: invoke other requests from within update callbacks
column323: invoke other requests from within update callbacks
column324: the way photos are downloaded changed during the layer update of the previous version, and fixing that bug as a breaking change in itself. client.download_media now offers a different way to deal with thumbnails.
column325: you can now use client.remove_event_handler and client.list_event_handlers similar how you could with normal updates.
column326: the old jsonsession finally replaces the original session . if you were overriding any of these, you should only worry about overriding session now.
column327: internally, another important change. the .on_send function on the tlobjects is gone, and now there s a new .to_bytes. from my tests, this has always been over twice as fast serializing objects, although more replacements need to be done, so please report any issues.
column328: updates are expanded, so you don t need to check if the update has .updates or an inner .update anymore.
column329: new cleaned-up method to stream downloads with client.iter_download, which offers a lot of flexibility, such as arbitrary offsets for efficient seeking.
column330: signing in now accounts for authrestarterror itself, and also handles passwordhashinvaliderror.
column331: updated documentation and added more examples.
column332: not only that, but more improvements have also been made: you re now able to both sign up and logout, watch a pretty uploading/downloading x% progress, and other minor changes which make using telethon easier.
column333: some other cool examples of things that you can do: when someone tells you hello , you can automatically reply with another hello without even needing to type it by yourself :)
column334: the logic for getting entities from their username is now correct.
column338: sending albums of photo urls is now supported.
column339: without rowid will only be used on the *.session if supported.
column343: you can now forward messages from different chats directly with client.forward_messages.
column344: some documentation updates and fixed to clarify certain things.
column345: you can now search messages with a from_user that s not a user. this is a telegram feature, we know the name isn t great, but backwards-compatibility has to be kept.
column346: fixes for readthedocs to correctly build the documentation.
column347: you can now annoy everyone with the new message.pin! the client has its own variant too, called client.pin_message.
column348: accessing .sender, .chat and similar may not work in events anymore, since previously they could access the network. the new rule is that properties are not allowed to make api calls. you should use .get_sender, .get_chat instead while using events. you can safely access properties if you get messages through client.get_messages or other methods in the client.
column349: when an entity is not found, it is searched in all dialogs. this might not always be desirable but it s more comfortable for legitimate uses.
column350: the username regex mentioned on usernameinvaliderror was invalid, but it has now been fixed.
column351: use the right peer type when a marked integer id is provided.
column352: the layer change from 82 to 91 changed a lot of things in the raw api, so be aware that if you rely on raw api calls, you may need to update your code, in particular if you work with files. they have a new file_reference parameter that you must provide.
column353: for some reason, telegram doesn t have enough with the inputpeer. there also exist inputchannel and inputuser! you don t have to worry about those anymore, it s handled internally now.
column354: invalidchecksumerror s are now ignored by the library.
column355: the time offset wasn t being used .
column356: much faster integer factorization when generating the required auth_key. thanks @delivrance for making me notice this, and for the pull request.
column357: new .get_drafts method with a custom draft class by @josxa.
column358: updates was being dispatched to raw handlers when it shouldn t.
column359: sending a message to a phone number was failing because the type used for a request had changed on layer 71.
column360: fix library was raising a generic connectionerror and not the one that actually occurred.
column361: sockets can now be closed properly.
column362: join all threads when calling .disconnect, to assert no dangling thread is left alive.
column363: updated some asserts and parallel downloads, as well as some fixes for sync.
column364: telethon used to crash a lot when logging in for the very first time. the reason for this was that the reconnection were not handled properly. now they are, so you should be able to login directly, without needing to delete the *.session file anymore. notice that downloading from a different dc is still a wip.
column365: the maximum file size limit has also been increased to 2gb on the server, so you can send even larger files.
column366: new common way to deal with retries .
column367: new .get_input_entity method, which makes use of the above feature. you should use this when a request needs a inputpeer, rather than the whole entity .
column368: primarily bug fixing and a few welcomed additions.
column369: you can now delete over 100 messages at once with client.delete_messages.
column370: reconnection used to fail because it tried invoking things from the readthread.
column371: you can now get comments in a channel post with the reply_to parameter in client.iter_messages. comments are messages that reply to a specific channel message, hence the name .
column372: to_id was not validated when retrieving messages by their ids.
column373: file attributes not being inferred for open ed files.
column374: there is a new magic telethon.sync module to let you use all the methods in the telegramclient in a synchronous way, while using asyncio behind the scenes! this means you re now able to do both of the following:
column375: client.send_file plays better with streams now.
column376: objects can no longer be content_related and instead subclass tlrequest, making the separation of concerns easier.
column377: .to_dict will now work even on invalid tlobject s.
column378: fixes to bugs introduced while making this release.
column379: message search was broken when using a certain combination of parameters.
column380: potentially fix alternative session storages that had issues with dates.
column381: calling getconfigrequest is now made less often.
column382: that s pretty much it, although there s more work to be done to make the overall experience of working with updates even better. stay tuned!
column383: another big thing, you can get entities by just their positive id. this may cause some collisions , and you can still be explicit about the type you want. however, it s a lot more convenient and less confusing.
column384: this update is overall an attempt to make telethon a bit more user friendly, along with some other stability enhancements, although it brings quite a few changes.
column385: added some missing cases on .get_input_entity and peer functions.
column386: you can now schedule messages to be sent at a later time, which can also work as reminders for yourself when used in your own chat!
column387: some improvements to the search in the full api and generated examples.
column388: a bit late to the party, but telethon now offers a convenient way to comment on channel posts. it works very similar to reply_to:
column389: improvements to the way marked ids are parsed.
column390: add auto-cast for inputmessage and inputlocation.
column391: fix client.send_file with the result of client.upload_file.
column392: it actually is a usable-enough client for your day by day. you could even add libnotify and pop, you re done! a great cli-client with desktop notifications.
column393: this version is primarily for people to migrate their .session files, which are pickled, to the new json format. although slightly slower, and a bit more vulnerable since it s plain text, it s a lot more resistant to upgrades.
column394: videos can now be included when sending albums.
column395: the library was accidentally using a deprecated argument in one of its friendly methods, producing a warning.
column396: you can prevent the entitydatabase from saving users by setting client.session.entities.enabled = false, and prevent the session from saving input entities at all by setting client.session.save_entities = false. you can also clear the cache for a certain user through client.session.entities.clear_cache, which will clear all if no entity is given.
column397: this is fine for small bots but it will add the callback every time you send a message, so you probably should do this instead once you are done testing:
column398: more checks to ensure that the connection is flagged correctly as either connected or not.
column399: libssl is no longer an optional dependency. use cryptg instead, which you can find on link
column400: thumbnails are sorted, so -1 is always the largest.
column401: exif metadata is respected when automatically resizing photos, so the orientation information should no longer be lost.
column402: large dates now wrap around a 32-bit integer, which is the only way we can represent them to telegram. even if wrong , it makes things not crash, and it s the best we can do with 32-bit dates.
column403: now you re able to send photo and document as files.
column404: the library now distinguishes between mtproto and api schemas.
column405: client.start was completely broken due to a last-time change requiring named arguments everywhere.
column406: the warning for added update handler but no workers set wasn t actually working.
column407: getting an entity by its positive id should be enough, regardless of their type . although wrapping them inside a peer is still recommended, it s not necessary.
column408: some important internal changes are that the old way to deal with rsa public keys now uses a different module instead the old strange hand-crafted version.
column409: even if you don t update, your code will still need to account for the fact that the sender of a message might be one of the accounts telegram introduced to preserve backwards compatibility, because this is a server-side change, so it s better to update and not lag behind. as it s mostly just a single person driving the project on their free time, bug-fixes are not backported.
column410: this code will leave a comment to the channel post with id 1134 in channel.
column411: you can invoke requests from update handlers. and any other thread. a new temporary will be made, so that you can be sending even several requests at the same time!
column412: .process_entities was being called from more places than only __call__.
