column413: telethon.telegram_client.telegramclient.forward_messages now returns a single item instead of a list if the input was also a single item.
column414: fixed incredibly slow imports under some systems due to expensive path resolution when searching for libssl.
column415: the documentation has been completely reworked from the ground up, with awesome new quick references such as client reference to help you quickly find what you need!
column416: fixed unicodedecodeerror when accessing the text of messages with malformed offsets in their entities.
column417: this update brings some big changes to the update system, so please read it if you work with them!
column418: sending a message with file= would ignore some of the parameters.
column419: now you should be able to sign in even if you have process_updates=true and no previous session.
column420: in some cases, there were issues when using events.album together with events.raw.
column421: code reusing for getting the chat and the sender, which easily enables this feature for new types.
column422: successful automatic reconnections now ask telegram to send updates to us once again as soon as the library is ready to listen for them.
column423: all inputpeer entities are saved in the session file, but you can disable this by setting save_entities=false.
column424: the library should more reliably handle certain updates with empty data.
column425: initial authorization on a new data center will retry up to 5 times by default.
column426: new telethon.utils.encode_waveform and telethon.utils.decode_waveform methods as implemented by telegram desktop, which lets you customize how voice notes will render.
column427: fix library was not expecting ioerror from pysocks.
column431: incoming messages from bots weren t working with whitelists.
column432: message.click now supports a password parameter, needed when doing things like changing the owner of a bot via @botfather.
column433: that s it, any new idea or suggestion about how to make the project even more friendly is highly appreciated.
column434: .get_entity now supports lists too, and it will make as little api calls as possible if you feed it inputpeer types. usernames will always be resolved, since they may have changed.
column435: with that out of the way, let s look at the full change set:
column436: you can also easily use this for sending files, playing games, etc.
column437: several updates and improvements to the documentation, such as optional dependencies now being properly listed.
column438: fixed a keyerror on certain cases with conversation.
column439: please refer to the wiki/usage modes for an in-depth description on how to work with updates now. notice that you cannot invoke requests from within handlers anymore, only the v.0.13.1 patch allowed you to do so.
column440: add missing .to_dict, __str__ and .stringify for tlmessage and messagecontainer.
column441: if you have been using telethon for a while, you probably know how annoying the could not find the input entity for error can be. in this new version, the library will try harder to find the input entity for you!
column442: new full api examples in the generated documentation.
column444: custom commands on setup.py are nicer to use.
column445: the entitydatabase will, by default, cache all the users, chats and channels you find in memory for as long as the program is running. the session will, by default, save all key-value pairs of the entity identifiers and their hashes .
column447: in an attempt to help everyone who works with the telegram api, telethon will by default report all remote procedure call errors to pwrtelegram, a public database anyone can query, made by daniil. all the information sent is a get request with the error code, error message and method used.
column448: if hachoir is available, the file metadata can now be extracted from streams and in-memory bytes.
column450: path-like files are now supported for thumbnails.
column451: tlobject.__repr__ doesn t show the original tl definition anymore, it was a lot of clutter. if you have any complaints open an issue and we can discuss it.
column452: phone code hash is associated with phone, so you can change your mind when calling .sign_in.
column454: utc timezone information is properly set for read datetime.
column455: urls like t.me/@username are now valid.
column456: cherry-picked a commit to use asyncio.open_connection in the lowest level of the library. do open issues if this causes trouble, but it should otherwise improve performance and reliability.
column457: state is now persisted to the session file.
column458: while those are the biggest things, there are still more things to be excited about.
column459: the library only offers the default sqlitesession again. see session files for more on how to use a different storage from now on.
column460: new client.edit_admin and client.edit_permissions methods to more easily manage your groups.
column461: some fixes regarding disconnecting on client deletion and properly saving the authorization key.
column462: tlobject s override __eq__ and __ne__, so you can compare them.
column463: internally, the '+' from the phone number is now stripped, since it shouldn t be included.
column464: since the content distributed network is not handled by telegram itself, the owners may tamper these files. telegram sends their sha256 sum for clients to implement this additional verification step, which now the library has. if any cdn has altered the file you re trying to download, cdnfiletamperederror will be raised to let you know.
column465: empty peers are excluded from the list of dialogs.
column466: you can also use the magic sync module in your own classes, and call sync.syncify to convert all their async def into magic variants.
column467: keyerror is now handled properly when forwarding messages.
column468: if you re one of those who love security the most, these are good news. you can now use two factor authentication with telethon too! as internal changes, the coding style has been improved, and you can easily use custom session objects, and various little bugs have been fixed.
column469: retry automatically on rpccallfailerror. this error happened a lot when iterating over many messages, and retrying often fixes it.
column470: phone numbers can have dashes, spaces, or parenthesis. they ll be removed before making the request.
column471: if you still would like to opt out, simply set client.session.report_errors = false to disable this feature. however daniil would really thank you if you helped him by keeping it on!
column472: client.inline_query now lets you specify the chat where the query is being made from, which some bots need to provide certain functionality.
column473: return as early as possible from .get_input_entity and similar, to avoid penalizing you for doing this right.
column474: the request that caused a rpc error is now shown in the error message.
column475: not many changes in this release, mostly the layer change. lately quite a few people have been reporting typenotfounderror, which occurs when the server sends types that it shouldn t. this can happen when telegram decides to add a new, incomplete layer, and then they change the layer without bumping the layer number . this layer change should fix it.
column476: the progress_callback for client.upload_file can now be an async def.
column477: using caption=none would raise an error instead of setting no caption.
column478: the telegramclient has been split into several mixin classes to avoid having a 3,000-lines-long file with all the methods.
column479: add missing caption when sending message with media.
column480: mtprotosender now relies more on the generated code to read responses.
column481: existing code will continue working, since the old .invoke has not been deprecated.
column482: the library now has a friendly method to perform qr-login, as detailed in link it won t generate qr images, but it provides a way for you to easily do so with any other library of your choice.
column483: important, related to the serialization. every object or request that had to serialize a true/false type was always being serialized as false!
column484: dealing with mimetypes should cause less issues in systems like windows.
column485: yes, really cool! i promise. even though this is meant to be a library, that doesn t mean it can t have a good interactive client for you to try the library out. this is why now you can do many, many things with the interactivetelegramclient:
column486: some nice things that were missing, along with the usual bug-fixes.
column487: fixed the return value when forwarding messages if some were missing and also the return value of albums.
column488: the update_workers and spawn_read_thread arguments are gone. simply remove them from your code when you create the client.
column489: sqlite s cursor should not be closed properly after usage.
column490: you can get messages by their id with telethon.telegram_client.telegramclient.get_messages s ids parameter:
column491: less flood waits when downloading media from different data centers, and the library will now detect them even before sending requests.
column492: fix disconnection without being logged in.
column493: outgoing tlmessage are now pre-packed so if there s an error when serializing the raw requests, the library will no longer swallow it. this also means re-sending packets doesn t need to re-pack their bytes.
column494: utils.resolve_bot_file_id now works again for photos.
column495: more special cases in the mtprotosender have been cleaned up, and also some attributes from the session which didn t really belong there since they weren t being saved.
column496: some issues with events when accessing the input chat or their media.
column497: fix method calls on the objects returned by client.iter_dialogs.
column498: the message object returned when sending a message with buttons wouldn t always contain the replymarkup.
column499: tgcrypto will now be used for encryption when installed.
column500: this update brings a lot of changes, so it would be nice if you could read the whole change log!
column501: telethon.telegram_client.telegramclient.download_file now supports a none path to return the file in memory and return its bytes.
column502: proxy connection is now blocking which should help avoid some errors.
column503: count was always none for message.button_count.
column504: use memorysession if sqlite3 is not installed by default.
column505: less rpc are made when accessing the .sender and .chat of some events .
column506: implemented .get_input_media helper methods. now you can even use another message as input media!
column507: more attempts at reducing cpu usage after automatically fetching missing entities on events. this isn t a big deal, even if it sounds like one.
column508: .set_proxy method, to avoid having to create a new telegramclient.
column509: events resolution is postponed until you are successfully connected, so you can attach them before starting the client.
column511: avoid joining the background thread on disconnect, as it would be none due to a race condition.
column512: the func= parameter of events can now be an async function.
column513: this will register the handler callback to handle new message events. note that you didn t add this to any client yet, and this is the key point: you don t need a client to define handlers! you can add it later:
column515: the callback parameter from telethon.tl.custom.button.button.inline was removed, since it had always been a bad idea. adding the callback there meant a lot of extra work for every message sent, and only registering it after the first message was sent! instead, use telethon.events.callbackquery.callbackquery.
column516: # this line adds the handler we defined before for new messages
column517: under some systems, libssl would fail to load earlier than expected, causing the library to fail when being imported.
column518: bug with certain input parameters when iterating messages.
column519: fixed draft not being aware of the entity.
column520: vales like random_id are now automatically inferred, so you can save yourself from the hassle of writing generate_random_long everywhere. same applies to .get_input_peer, unless you really need the extra performance provided by skipping one if if called manually.
column521: fix forward had its client as none.
column522: you can reuse message buttons to send new messages with those buttons.
column526: the no_webpage parameter from .send_message has been renamed to link_preview for clarity, so now it does the opposite .
column527: flood waits of zero seconds are handled better.
column528: sending large files in albums would fail because it tried to cache them.
column529: removed named length argument in to_bytes for pypy.
column530: cdn downloads weren t working properly, and now a few patches have been applied to ensure more reliability, although i couldn t personally test this, so again, report any feedback.
column531: it s here, it has come! the library now supports ipv6! just pass use_ipv6=true when creating a telegramclient. note that i could not test this feature because my machine doesn t have ipv6 setup. if you know ipv6 works in your machine but the library doesn t, please refer to #425.
column532: downloading a thumbnail by index should now use the correct size ordering.
column533: new message.file property! now you can trivially access message.file.id to get the file id of some media, or even print.
column534: as a side note, the documentation at link now lists known rpcerror for all requests, so you know what to expect. this required a major rewrite, but it was well worth it!
column535: you can no longer pass a batch_size when iterating over messages. no other method exposed this parameter, and it was only meant for testing purposes. instead, it s now a private constant.
column536: when trying to client.start to another account if you were previously logged in, the library will now warn you because this is probably not intended. to avoid the warning, make sure you re logging in to the right account or logout from the other first.
column537: a lot of people use ids thinking this is the right way of doing it. ideally, you would always use input_*, not sender or sender_id . but, with this change, ids will work just the same as input_* inside events.
column538: fix markdown/html parser from failing with leading/trailing whitespace.
column539: some new things and patches that already deserved their own release.
column540: the session would fail to load if the auth_key had been removed manually.
column541: stability regarding transport-level errors should be improved. in particular, you should no longer be getting unnecessarily logged out.
column542: new client.forward_messages, with its own wrapper on events, called event.forward_to.
column543: py:obj is the default sphinx s role which simplifies .rst files.
column544: accessing the .text of the newmessage event was failing due to a bug with the markdown unparser.
column545: .get_input_peer was ignoring a case for inputpeerself.
column546: this brings telethon a whole step closer to v1.0, though more things should preferably be changed.
column547: you can now configure the reply markup when using button as a bot.
column548: fix client.action not returning itself when used in a context manager .
column549: you can now send multiple requests at once while preserving the order:
column550: force_document=true was being ignored for albums.
column551: messages you send to yourself are now considered outgoing, unless they are forwarded.
column552: there used to be an exception when logging exceptions on update handlers.
column553: the method used to download documents crashed because two lines were swapped.
column554: methods to send message and media now support a ``reply_to`` parameter.
column555: receiving new updates shouldn t miss any anymore, also, periodic pings are back again so it should work on the long run.
column556: .send_message supports parse_mode='md' for markdown! it works in a similar fashion to the official clients . please report any issues with emojies or enhancements for the parser!
column558: fixed some issues regarding markdown and html parsing.
column559: when editing inline messages, the text parameter is preferred if provided.
column560: all the .get_ methods in the telegramclient now have a .iter_ counterpart, so you can do operations while retrieving items from them. for instance, you can client.iter_dialogs and break once you find what you re looking for instead fetching them all at once.
column561: lost messages are now properly skipped.
column562: client.kick_participant now returns the service message about the user being kicked, so you can delete it.
column563: the library should now be able to reliably download very large files.
column568: client.connect no longer returns true on success. instead, you should except the possible connectionerror and act accordingly. this makes it easier to not ignore the error.
column569: this release implements the http connection mode to the library, which means certain proxies that only allow http connections should now work properly. you can use it doing the following, like any other mode:
column570: better file cache. all files under 10mb, once uploaded, should never be needed to be re-uploaded again, as the sent media is cached to the session.
column571: you will be warned if you call .add_update_handler with no update_workers.
column572: the sqlite is now closed properly on disconnection.
column573: due to the layer change, you can no longer download photos with just their photosize. version 1.7.1 introduces a new way to download thumbnails to work around this issue.
column575: additional senders are unconditionally disconnected when disconnecting the main client, which should reduce the amount of asyncio warnings.
column576: errors are now un-pickle-able once again.
column577: support for python 3.4 in the sync version, and fix media download.
column578: running code with python3 -o would remove critical code from asserts.
column579: this page lists all the available versions of the library, in chronological order. you should read this when upgrading the library to know where your code can break, and where it can take advantage of new goodies!
column580: new properties on events.newmessage, like .video_note and .gif to access only specific types of documents.
column581: -404 errors are now detected when first connecting to a new data center.
column583: .get_message_history was failing when retrieving items that had messages forwarded from a channel.
column584: sending documents in inline queries should now work fine.
column585: assert that either all or none dependent-flag parameters are set before sending the request.
column586: the parse_mode for messages now accepts a callable.
column588: any file object can now be used to download a file instead a file name).
column591: this release should really improve the experience with the background thread that the library starts to read things from the network as soon as it can, but i can t spot every use case, so please report any bug .
column592: all the methods in the telethon.telegram_client.telegramclient that used to return a message will now return this object instead, which means you can do things like the following:
column593: some short usernames like @vote were being ignored.
column594: events are only built once and reused many times, which should save quite a few cpu cycles if you have a lot of the same type.
column595: this is a big release! quite a few things have been added to the library, such as the new conversation. this makes it trivial to get tokens from @botfather:
column596: more date types supported to represent a date parameter.
column597: special mention to some of the other changes in the 1.16.x series:
column599: invite links of the form tg://join?invite= now work.
column600: raw methods also warn you when a friendly variant is available, so that you don t accidentally make your life harder than it has to be.
column601: you must upgrade to this version before any higher one if you ve used telethon v0.10. if you happen to upgrade to an higher version, that s okay, but you will have to manually delete the *.session file, and logout from that session from an official client.
column602: downloading files from cdn s will not work yet .
column603: documentation fixes and some missing await.
column604: did you know that you can pretty print any result telegram returns by using their .stringify function? great for debugging!
column605: fixed some errors when installing telethon via pip .
column606: there were some @property async def left, and some await property.
column607: improved documentation and the online method reference at link
column608: video files are sent as a video by default unless force_document.
column609: client.send_file now accepts message s and messagemedia s as the file parameter.
column610: full support for different dcs and ++stable
column611: full support for different dcs and ++stable
column612: full support for different dcs and ++stable
column614: .get_dialogs now returns a single list instead a tuple consisting of a custom class that should make everything easier to work with.
column615: temporary fix for abusive duplicated updates.
column616: the mentioned different connection modes, and a new thread.
column617: markdown s url regex was not accepting newlines.
column618: you can now pass phone and phone_code_hash in client.sign_up, although you probably don t need that.
column619: several requests at once and upload compression
column620: several requests at once and upload compression
column621: several requests at once and upload compression
column623: fix invalid assertion regarding flag parameters as well.
column624: list dialogs and pick any you wish.
column625: getting the display name for forbidden chats now works.
column626: the mentioned method to start a new client.conversation.
column627: thanks to the overhaul of all client.iter_* methods, you can now do:
column631: if you come from telethon pre-1.0 you really want to read compatibility and convenience to port your scripts to the new version.
column632: .stringify and string representation for custom dialog/draft.
column633: fix forcibly getting the sender or chat from events would not always return all their information.
column635: fixed a rare infinite loop bug in client.iter_dialogs for some people.
column636: the mentioned reverse parameter when iterating over messages.
column638: better and more powerful setup.py gen command.
column639: client.delete_dialog now handles deactivated chats more gracefully.
column640: accessing the buttons of a custom message wouldn t work in channels, which lead to fix a completely different bug regarding starting bots.
column641: getting updates after reconnect should be more reliable.
column642: both lists have a .total attribute so you can still know how many dialogs/messages are in total.
column643: a bug under some session files where the sender would export authorization for the same data center, which is unsupported.
column645: you can now easily start takeout sessions through client.takeout. some of the requests will have lower flood limits when done through the takeout session.
column646: getting the pinned message in a chat was failing.
column647: more bug fixes and a few others addition to make events easier to use.
column648: setup.py now makes use of python_requires.
column649: fixed incorrect formatting of some errors.
column650: new in-memory cache for input entities. this should mean a lot less of disk look-ups.
column651: you can now .get_entity through exact name match instead username.
column652: improved conversation.cancel behaviour. now you can use it from anywhere.
column654: the low-level socket doesn t use a handcrafted timeout anymore, which should benefit by avoiding the arbitrary sleep that there used to be.
column655: some non-persisting properties from the session have been moved out.
column656: new telethon.utils.get_peer, useful when you expect a peer.
column657: add search, filter and from_user parameters to telethon.telegram_client.telegramclient.iter_messages.
column658: improved image detection. now you can easily send bytes and streams of images as photos, unless you force document.
column659: fix unhandled error when sending requests that were too big.
column662: a very quick follow-up release to fix a tiny bug with .send_message, no new features.
column663: proxyconnectionerror should properly be passed to the main thread for you to handle.
column664: wrong access to a member on chat forbidden error for .get_participants. an empty list is returned instead.
column665: fixed memory cycle in forward which let you do things like the following:
column666: new addition to the interactive client example to show peer information.
column667: messageempty is now handled when searching messages.
column671: events.album should now handle albums from different data centers more gracefully.
column672: determining the right path when downloading any file was very weird, now it s been enhanced.

column2: onset_strength parameter centering has been deprecated and renamed to center
column3: removed features and api changes
column4: the following features have been deprecated, and will be removed in 0.7.0:
column5: interactive plotting is now supported via ticker and formatter objects
column6: logamplitude is deprecated in favor of amplitude_to_db or power_to_db. the ref_power parameter has been renamed to ref.
column7: cqt now uses tuning=0.0 by default, rather than estimating the tuning from the signal. tuning estimation is still supported, and enabled by default for chroma analysis .
column8: #917 the output module is now deprecated, and will be removed in version 0.8.
column9: librosa.util.example_audio_file is now deprecated in favor of librosa.util.example.
column10: removed features
column11: resampling is now handled by the resampy library
column12: spectrogram frames are now centered, rather than left-aligned. this removes the need for window correction in librosa.frames_to_time
column13: removed deprecated a440 parameter from hz_to_octs, octs_to_hz, and chroma features
column14: beat and tempo
column15: fixed alignment errors with offset and duration in load
column16: #627 the following functions and features have been removed:
column17: deprecated functions
column18: removed deprecated util.roll_sparse function
column19: #621 dtw is now symmetric with respect to input arguments. stefan balke
column20: librosa.logamplitude now supports functional reference power, in addition to scalar values
column21: #735 added librosa.times_like and librosa.samples_like to generate time and sample indices corresponding to an existing feature matrix or shape specification. steve tjoa
column22: librosa.feature.chromagram and logfsgram now use power instead of energy
column23: #755 forward support and future-proofing for fancy indexing with numpy>1.15. brian mcfee
column24: features
column25: features
column26: features
column27: features
column28: #802 librosa.icqt inverse constant-q transform has been completely rewritten and is more numerically stable. brian mcfee
column29: chroma now starts at c by default, instead of a
column30: new features
column31: new features
column32: new features
column33: new features
column34: new features
column35: new features
column36: new features
column37: new features
column38: new features
column39: new features
column40: new features
column41: new features
column42: new features
column43: new features
column44: api changes and compatibility
column45: api changes and compatibility
column46: api changes and compatibility
column47: librosa.decompose.hpss with mask=true now returns soft masks, rather than binary masks.
column48: core io and dsp
column49: librosa.load supports offset and duration parameters
column50: deprecations to be removed in 0.9
column51: #1031 fixed errors in dynamic time warping with nan inputs and detection of invalid warping paths. frank zalkow, brian mcfee
column52: librosa.display.specshow now plots using pcolormesh, and supports non-uniform time and frequency axes.
column53: magma is now the default sequential colormap.
column54: librosa.get_duration can now operate directly on filenames as well as audio buffers and feature matrices.
column55: removed the deprecated output module.
column56: added a warning if scikits.samplerate is not detected
column57: added optional trimming to librosa.segment.stack_memory
column58: input validation and better exception reporting for most functions
column59: added demo notebooks for the librosa.effects and librosa.util.featureextractor
column60: built with sphinx using a theme provided by read the docs.
column61: pad_center supports multi-dimensional input and axis parameter
column62: #1171 automatic precision inference for spectral transforms and explicit control for librosa.cqt. brian mcfee
column63: librosa.cqt and librosa.feature.logfsgram now use the same parameter formats .
column64: #308 librosa.cqt default filter_scale parameter is now 1 instead of 2.
column65: added time-series or spectrogram input options to chromagram, logfsgram, melspectrogram, and mfcc
column66: removed deprecated amin parameter from icqt
column67: all plots can be rendered in natural coordinates
column68: fixed issue #102: segment.agglomerative no longer depends on the deprecated ward module of sklearn; it now depends on the newer agglomerative module.
column69: fixed bugs in find_files with negative slicing
column70: advanced examples
column71: #616 write_wav no longer supports integer-typed waveforms. this is due to enforcing consistency with librosa.util.valid_audio checks elsewhere in the codebase. if you have existing code that requires integer-valued output, consider using soundfile.write instead.
column72: #1054 fixed the length of signals produced by librosa.tone. brian mcfee
column73: #818 thanks to np.fft.rfft, functions stft, istft, ifgram, and fmt are faster and have a reduced memory footprint. brian mcfee
column74: librosa.autocorrelate now persists type for complex input
column75: changed default beat tracker settings
column76: major rewrite and reformatting of documentation
column77: added librosa.features.delta for computing temporal difference features
column78: new function librosa.get_duration computes the duration of an audio signal or spectrogram-like input matrix
column79: accelerated librosa.stft and ifgram
column80: fixed stability issues with ifgram, added options to suppress negative frequencies.
column81: optimized default parameters for librosa.onset.onset_detect
column82: fixed an edge-padding issue with decompose.hpss which resulted in percussive noise leaking into the harmonic component.
column83: #620 updated requirements to prevent installation with sklearn 0.19.0. brian mcfee
column84: librosa.magphase to separate magnitude and phase from a complex matrix
column85: #845 librosa.load: replaced the default audio decoder with pysoundfile, and only use audioread as backup. brian mcfee
column86: #295 librosa.display.frequency_ticks: like time_ticks. ticks can now dynamically adapt to scale and use automatic precision formatting . brian mcfee
column87: fixed a bug in tempo estimation with short windows
column88: removed all mutable object default parameters
column89: root mean square error has been renamed to rms.
column90: removed deprecated ifgram function.
column91: librosa.decompose.hpss can now return masking matrices
column92: librosa.feature.sync now supports 1d arrays
column93: iirt now uses sos mode by default.
column94: deprecation and moved-function warnings
column95: seaborn integration has been removed, and the display submodule now requires matplotlib >= 1.5.
column96: #416 librosa.output.write_wav only normalizes floating point, and normalization is disabled by default. brian mcfee
column97: #971 beat and tempo estimation now support prior distributions. brian mcfee
column98: moved feature.sync to librosa.util.sync and expanded its functionality
column99: cqt now returns properly scaled outputs that are continuous across octave boundaries. this breaks backwards compatibility with the 0.4 series.
column100: librosa.autocorrelate can now operate along any axis of multi-dimensional input
column101: #279 librosa.cqt now provides complex-valued output with argument real=false. this will become the default behavior in subsequent releases.
column102: #857 librosa.cqt and librosa.icqt forward and inverse constant-q transform now support custom resampling modes. brian mcfee
column103: #1125 updates to librosa.util.frame to remove default parameters and relax contiguity restrictions. brian mcfee
column104: standardized n_fft=2048 for piptrack, ifptrack , and logfsgram
column105: added option centering to librosa.onset.onset_strength to resolve frame-centering issues with sliding window stft
column106: the following functions, classes, and constants have been removed:
column107: #966 librosa.util.frame now supports multidimensional data. includes a new helper function librosa.util.stack for contiguous concatenation. brian mcfee
column108: fixed a context scoping error in librosa.load with some audioread backends
column109: changed default parameters in onset detection, beat tracking
column110: added boolean input support for librosa.display.cmap
column111: #337 librosa.segment.recurrence_matrix can now produce weighted affinities and distances. brian mcfee
column112: internal refactoring and restructuring of submodules
column113: changed default librosa.decompose.hpss window to 31
column114: librosa.onset.onset_strength now takes generic spectrogram function feature
column115: #776 librosa.piptrack now supports a keyword argument, ref=none, allowing users to override the reference thresholding behavior for determining which bins correspond to pitches. brian mcfee
column116: broke compatibilty with ifgram.m; librosa.ifgram now matches stft
column117: fixed a bug in beat trimming
column118: #1165 removed deprecated optional_jit decorator

column2: while discovering a python executables interpreters that cannot be queried are now displayed with info level rather than warning, so now they re no longer shown by default - by @gaborbernat.
column3: also generate pipx.y console script beside pip-x.y to be compatible with how pip installs itself - by @gaborbernat.
column4: fix pypy 2 builtin modules are imported from standard library, rather than from builtin - by @gaborbernat.
column5: periodically upgrade the embedded wheels in a background process, and use them if they have been released for more than 28 days
column6: built in discovery class is always preferred over plugin supplied classes.
column7: fixes typos, repeated words and inconsistent heading spacing. rephrase parts of the development documentation and cli documentation. expands shorthands like env var and config to their full forms. uses descriptions from respective documentation, for projects listed in related links - by @pradyunsg.
column8: fix download is true by default - by @gaborbernat.
column9: add --read-only-app-data option to allow for creation based on an existing app data cache which is non-writable. this may be useful to produce a docker image where the app-data is pre-populated.
column10: check if the application data path passed in does not exist or is read-only, and fallback to a temporary directory,
column11: bump embedded pip and setuptools packages to latest upstream supported - by @gaborbernat.
column12: on python 2 with apple framework builds the global site package is no longer added when the system-site-packages is not specified - by @gaborbernat.
column13: align with venv module when creating virtual environments with builtin creator on windows 3.7 and later - by @gaborbernat.
column14: fail with better error message if trying to install source with unsupported setuptools, allow setuptools-scm >= 2 and move to legacy setuptools-scm format to support better older platforms - by @gaborbernat.
column15: disable distutils fixup for python 3 until pypa/pip #7778 is fixed and released - by @gaborbernat.
column16: the python specification can now take one or more values, first found is used to create the virtual environment - by @gaborbernat.
column17: first public release of the rewrite. everything is brand new and just added.
column18: fix prompt not displayed correctly with upcoming fish 3.10 due to us not preserving $pipestatus - by @krobelus.
column19: upgrade embedded setuptools to 50.2.0 and pip to 20.2.3 - by @gaborbernat.
column20: the application data folder is now controllable via app-data,
column21: project readme is now of type markdown instead of restructuredtext - by @gaborbernat.
column22: fix virtualenv fails sometimes when run concurrently, --clear-app-data conflicts with clear flag when abbreviation is turned on. to bypass this while allowing abbreviated flags on the command line we had to move it to reset-app-data - by @gaborbernat.
column23: the app-data seeder no longer symlinks the packages on unix and copies on windows. instead by default always copies, however now has the symlink-app-data flag allowing users to request this less robust but faster method - by @gaborbernat.
column24: fix circular prefix reference with single elements - by @gaborbernat.
column25: better handling of options copies and symlinks. introduce priority of where the option is set to follow the order: cli, env var, file, hardcoded. if both set at same level prefers copy over symlink. - by @gaborbernat.
column26: fix cpython is not discovered from windows registry, and discover pythons from windows registry in decreasing order by version - by @gaborbernat.
column27: generate ignore file for version control systems to avoid tracking virtual environments by default. users should remove these files if still want to track. for now we support only git by @gaborbernat.
column28: when discovering interpreters on windows, via the pep-514, prefer pythoncore releases over other ones. virtualenv is used via pip mostly by this distribution, so prefer it over other such as conda - by @gaborbernat.
column29: fix entry points are not populated for editable installs on python 2 due to setuptools working set being calculated before easy_install.pth runs - by @gaborbernat.
column30: beside the prefix folder also try with the platform dependent binary folder within that,
column31: passing in the virtual environment name/path is now required - by @gaborbernat.
column32: fix generated scripts use host version info rather than target - by @gaborbernat.
column33: allow unfunctioning of pydoc to fail freely so that virtualenvs can be activated under zsh with set -e - by @d125q.
column34: creating virtual environments in parallel fail with cannot acquire lock within app data - by @gaborbernat.
column35: stable order within pyenv.cfg and add include-system-site-packages only for creators that reference a global python - by user:gaborbernat.
column36: fix losing of libpypy-c.so when the pypy executable is a symlink - by @asottile
column37: print out a one line message about the created virtual environment when no verbose is set, this can now be silenced to get back the original behaviour via the quiet flag - by @pradyunsg.
column38: when copying do not copy the permission bits, last access time, last modification time, and flags as access to these might be forbidden and these are not needed for the user to use the virtual environment - by @gaborbernat.
column39: built with sphinx using a theme provided by read the docs.
column40: fix global site package always being added with bundled macos python framework builds - by @gaborbernat.
column41: symlink-app-data is always false when the application data is temporary
column42: always resolve system_executable information during the interpreter discovery, and the discovered environment is the system interpreter instead of the venv/virtualenv ,
column43: fix startup on python 2 is slower for virtualenv - this was due to setuptools calculating it s working set distribution - by @gaborbernat.
column44: support python 2 implementations that require the landmark files and site.py to be in platform standard library instead of the standard library path of the virtual environment - by @gaborbernat.
column45: improve error message when the host python does not satisfy invariants needed to create virtual environments - by @gaborbernat.
column46: generate bash and fish activators on windows too - by @gaborbernat.
column47: the builtin discovery takes now a --try-first-with argument and is first attempted as valid interpreters. one can use this to force discovery of a given python executable when the discovery order/mechanism raises errors - by @gaborbernat.
column48: report of the created virtual environment is now split across four short lines rather than one long - by @gaborbernat
column49: fixed cannot discover a python interpreter that has already been discovered under a different path - by @gaborbernat.
column50: allow virtualenv s app data cache to be overridden by virtualenv_override_app_data - by @asottile.
column51: allow the test suite to pass even when called with the system python - to help repackaging of the tool for linux distributions - by @gaborbernat.
column52: support broken packaging pythons that put the include headers under distutils pattern rather than sysconfig one - by @gaborbernat.
column53: temporary directory application data is automatically cleaned up at the end of execution,
column54: fix that when the app-data seeders image creation fails the exception is silently ignored. avoid two virtual environment creations to step on each others toes by using a lock while creating the base images. by @gaborbernat.
column55: the current virtualenv is the second iteration of implementation. from version 0.8 all the way to 16.7.9 we numbered the first iteration. version 20.0.0b1 is a complete rewrite of the package, and as such this release history starts from there. the old changelog is still available in the legacy branch documentation.
column56: fix download fails with python 3.4 - by @gaborbernat.
column57: bump embed pip to 20.3.3, setuptools to 51.1.1 and wheel to 0.36.2 - by @gaborbernat.
column58: lower minimal version of six required to 1.9 - by ssbarnea
column59: add a cli flag that triggers upgrade of embedded wheels under upgrade-embed-wheels
column60: allow seed wheel files inside the extra-search-dir folders that do not have requires-python metadata specified, these are considered compatible with all python versions - by @gaborbernat.
column61: virtual environments created via relative path on windows creates bad console executables - by @gaborbernat.
column62: seeder pip now correctly handles --extra-search-dir - by @frenzymadness.
column63: allow the use of / as pathname component separator on windows - by vphilippon
column64: document requirements when installing via pip under the installation section - by @gaborbernat.
column65: on windows python 3.7+ distributions where the exe shim is missing fallback to the old ways - by @gaborbernat.
column66: no longer preimport threading to fix support for gpython and gevent - by @navytux.
column67: extend environment variables checked for configuration to also check aliases - by @gaborbernat.
column68: relax importlib.resources requirement to also allow version 2 - by @asottile.
column69: bash activation script should have no extensions instead of .sh - by @gaborbernat.
column70: provide correct path for bash activator in cygwin or msys2 - by @danyeaw.
column71: upgrade embedded pip to 20.2.1 and setuptools to 49.4.0 - by @gaborbernat.
column72: fix discovery of interpreter by name from path that does not match a spec format - by @gaborbernat.
column73: after importing virtualenv passing cwd to a subprocess calls breaks with invalid directory - by @gaborbernat.
column74: allow missing .py files if a compiled .pyc version is available - by @tucked.
column75: fine tune the documentation layout: default width of theme, allow tables to wrap around, soft corners for code snippets - by @pradyunsg.
column76: upgrade pip for python 2.7 and 3.5+ from 20.0.2 to 20.1 - by @gaborbernat.
column77: seems sometimes venvs created set their base executable to themselves; we accept these without question, so we handle virtual environments as system pythons causing issues - by @gaborbernat.
column78: upgrade embedded pip to 20.2.1, setuptools to 49.6.0 and wheel to 0.35.1 - by @gaborbernat.
column79: fix acquiring python information might be altered by distutils configuration files generating incorrect layout virtual environments - by @gaborbernat.
column80: do not print error message if the application exists with systemexit - by @gaborbernat.
column81: fix processing of the virtualenv_python environment variable and make it multi-value as well - by @pneff.
column82: add link to the legacy documentation for the changelog by @jezdez.
column83: fix pinning seed packages via app-data seeder raised invalid requirement - by @gaborbernat.
column84: fix activate_this.py throws attributeerror on windows when virtual environment was created via cross python mechanism - by @gaborbernat.
column85: fix pypy3 stdlib on windows is incorrect - by @gaborbernat.
column86: fallback to unverified context when querying the pypi for release date,
column87: show less information when we run with a single verbosity :
column88: support python 3 framework distributed via xcode in macos catalina and before - by @gaborbernat.
column89: automatically create the application data folder if it does not exists - by @gaborbernat.
column90: fix windows store python support, do not allow creation via symlink as that s not going to work by design - by @gaborbernat.
column91: fix list configuration value parsing from config file or environment variable - by @gaborbernat.
column92: better logging output while running and enable logging on background process call
column93: on the programmatic api allow passing in the environment variable dictionary to use, defaults to os.environ if not specified - by @gaborbernat.
column94: drop cached python information if the system executable is no longer present - by @gaborbernat.
column95: for activation scripts always use unix line endings - by @saytosid.
column96: do not fail when the pyc files is missing for the host python 2 - by @gaborbernat.
column97: do not fail if there are executables that fail to query on the path,
column98: also create pythonx.x executables when creating pypy virtualenvs - by @asottile
column99: supports details now explicitly what python installations we support - by @gaborbernat.
column100: no longer shows accepted interpreters information ,
column101: upgrade embedded setuptools to 46.4.0 from 46.1.3 on python 3.5+, and pip from 20.1 to 20.1.1 - by @gaborbernat.
column102: avoid spawning new windows when doing seed package upgrades in the background on windows - by @gaborbernat.
column103: fix system python discovery mechanism when prefixes contain relative parts by resolving paths within the python information query - by @gaborbernat.
column104: fix a bug that reading and writing on the same file may cause race on multiple processes.
column105: upgrade embedded pip from version 20.1.2 to 20.2 - by @gaborbernat.
column106: how distributions should handle shipping their own embedded wheels at embed wheels for distributions - by @gaborbernat.
column107: when aliasing interpreters, use relative symlinks - by @asottile.
column108: upgrade pip to 20.2.1 and setuptools to 49.2.1 - by @gaborbernat.
column109: upgrade embedded setuptools to 44.1.1 for python 2 and 47.1.1 for python3.5+ - by @gaborbernat.
column110: ship wheels for python 3.9 and 3.10
column111: fix batch activation script shell prompt to display environment name by default - by @spetafree.

column113: fix symlink detection for creators - by @asottile
column114: add a cli flag with-traceback that allows displaying the stacktrace of the virtualenv when a failure occurs - by @gaborbernat.

column154: features - 20.2.0

column2: trio.queue's join and task_done methods are deprecated without replacement
column3: remove all the apis deprecated in 0.9.0 or earlier , trio.brokenstreamerror, and trio.resourcebusyerror), except for trio.hazmat.unboundedqueue, which stays for now since it is used by the obscure lowlevel functions monitor_completion_queue and monitor_kevent.
column4: run_sync_in_worker_thread is deprecated in favor of trio.to_thread.run_sync.
column5: the nursery context manager was rewritten to avoid use of @asynccontextmanager and @async_generator. this reduces extraneous frames in exception traces and addresses bugs regarding stopiteration and stopasynciteration exceptions not propagating correctly.
column6: resourcebusyerror is now a deprecated alias for the new busyresourceerror, and brokenstreamerror is a deprecated alias for the new brokenresourceerror.
column7: trio 0.2.0 contains changes from 14 contributors, and brings major new features and bug fixes, as well as a number of deprecations and a very small number of backwards incompatible changes. we anticipate that these should be easy to adapt to, but make sure to read about them below, and if you re using trio then remember to read and subscribe to issue #1.
column8: deprecate trio.open_cancel_scope in favor of trio.cancelscope, which more clearly reflects that creating a cancel scope is just an ordinary object construction and does not need to be immediately paired with entering it.
column9: trio 0.1.0 provided a set of built-in mechanisms for waiting for and tracking the result of individual tasks. we haven t yet found any cases where using this actually led to simpler code, though, and this feature is blocking useful improvements, so the following are being deprecated without replacement:
column10: trio no longer crashes when an async function is implemented in c or cython and then passed directly to trio.run or nursery.start_soon.
column11: trio.open_tcp_stream has a new local_address= keyword argument that can be used on machines with multiple ip addresses to control which ip is used for the outgoing connection.
column12: the trio.hazmat.parkinglot class was rewritten to be simpler and faster
column13: introspecting and extending trio with trio.lowlevel
column14: add support for trio.queue with capacity=0. queue s implementation is also faster now.
column15: we ve slightly relaxed our definition of which trio operations act as checkpoints. a trio async function that exits by throwing an exception is no longer guaranteed to execute a checkpoint; it might or might not. the rules are unchanged for async functions that don t exit with an exception, async iterators, and async context managers. trio.testing.assert_checkpoints has been updated to reflect the new behavior: if its with block exits with an exception, no assertion is made.
column16: most of the public classes that trio exports like trio.lock, trio.socketstream, and so on weren t designed with subclassing in mind. and we ve noticed that some users were trying to subclass them anyway, and ending up with fragile code that we re likely to accidentally break in the future, or else be stuck unable to make changes for fear of breaking subclasses.
column17: current_default_worker_thread_limiter is deprecated in favor of trio.to_thread.current_default_thread_limiter.
column18: suppose one task is blocked trying to use a resource for example, reading from a socket and while it s doing this, another task closes the resource. previously, this produced undefined behavior. now, closing a resource causes pending operations on that resource to terminate immediately with a closedresourceerror. closedstreamerror and closedlistenererror are now aliases for closedresourceerror, and deprecated. for this to work, trio needs to know when a resource has been closed. to facilitate this, new functions have been added: trio.hazmat.notify_fd_close and trio.hazmat.notify_socket_close. if you re using trio s built-in wrappers like socketstream or trio.socket, then you don t need to worry about this, but if you re using the low-level functions like trio.hazmat.wait_readable, you should make sure to call these functions at appropriate times.
column19: remove blockingtrioportal: it was deprecated in 0.12.0.
column20: add trio.process.stdio, which is a stapledstream of stdin and stdout if both of those are available, and none otherwise. this is intended to make it more ergonomic to speak a back-and-forth protocol with a subprocess.
column21: on windows, the iocp subsystem is generally the best way to implement async i/o operations but it s historically been weak at providing select-style readiness notifications, like trio.hazmat.wait_readable and wait_writable. we aren t willing to give those up, so previously trio s windows backend used a hybrid of select + iocp. this was complex, slow, and had limited scalability.
column22: we cleaned up the distinction between the abstract channel interface and the memory channel concrete implementation. trio.abc.sendchannel and trio.abc.receivechannel have been slimmed down, trio.memorysendchannel and trio.memoryreceivechannel are now public types that can be used in type hints, and there s a new trio.abc.channel interface for future bidirectional channels.
column23: trio s default internal clock is now based on time.perf_counter instead of time.monotonic. this makes time-keeping more precise on windows, and has no effect on other platforms.
column24: control-c handling on windows now uses signal.set_wakeup_fd and should be more reliable
column25: fortunately, we found a way to implement wait_* with iocp, so trio s windows backend has been completely rewritten, and now uses iocp exclusively. as a user, the only difference you should notice is that trio should now be faster on windows, and can handle many more sockets. this also simplified the code internally, which should allow for more improvements in the future.
column26: and this would start the server running in the background in the nursery, and then give you back the random port it selected but not until it had finished initializing and was ready to accept requests!
column27: add synchronous .close methods and context manager support for memorysendchannel and memoryreceivechannel.
column28: we ve also added comprehensive support for ssl/tls encryption, including sni , starttls, renegotiation during full-duplex usage , and applying encryption to arbitrary streams, which allows for interesting applications like tls-over-tls. see: trio.open_ssl_over_tcp_stream, trio.serve_ssl_over_tcp, trio.open_ssl_over_tcp_listeners, and trio.ssl.
column29: multierror now defines its exceptions attribute in __init__ to better support linters and code autocompletion.
column30: for consistency with the new start method, the nursery spawn method is being renamed to start_soon
column31: if you re currently using trio.socket then you should switch to using our new high-level networking api instead. it takes care of many tiresome details, it s fully integrated with the abstract stream api, and it provides niceties like a state-of-the-art happy eyeballs implementation in open_tcp_stream and server helpers that integrate with nursery.start.
column32: remove all the apis deprecated in 0.3.0 and 0.4.0.
column33: blockingtrioportal has been deprecated in favor of the new trio.from_thread.
column34: fix regression introduced with cancellation changes in 0.12.0, where a trio.cancelscope which isn t cancelled could catch a propagating trio.cancelled exception if shielding were changed while the cancellation was propagating.
column35: threading interfaces have been reworked: run_sync_in_worker_thread is now trio.to_thread.run_sync, and instead of blockingtrioportal, use trio.from_thread.run and trio.from_thread.run_sync. what s neat about this is that these cooperate, so if you re in a thread created by to_thread.run_sync, it remembers which trio created it, and you can call trio.from_thread.* directly without having to pass around a blockingtrioportal object everywhere.
column36: add support for contextvars , and add trio.hazmat.runvar as a similar api for run-local variables. deprecate trio.tasklocal and trio.hazmat.runlocal in favor of these new apis.
column37: trio.current_instruments is deprecated. for adding or removing instrumentation at run-time, see trio.hazmat.add_instrument and trio.hazmat.remove_instrument
column38: the tiebreaker argument to trio.testing.wait_all_tasks_blocked has been deprecated. this is a highly obscure feature that was probably never used by anyone except trio.testing.mockclock, and mockclock doesn t need it anymore.
column39: new and improved apis for inter-task communication: trio.abc.sendchannel, trio.abc.receivechannel, and trio.open_memory_channel . this interface uses separate sender and receiver objects, for consistency with other communication interfaces like stream. also, the two objects can now be closed individually, making it much easier to gracefully shut down a channel. also, check out the nifty clone api to make it easy to manage shutdown in multiple-producer/multiple-consumer scenarios. also, the api has been written to allow for future channel implementations that send objects across process boundaries. also, it supports unbounded buffering if you really need it. also, help i can t stop writing also. see using channels to pass values between tasks for more details.
column40: removed everything that was deprecated in 0.2.0; see the 0.2.0 release notes below for details.
column41: trio.process on posix systems no longer accepts the error-prone combination of shell=false with a command that s a single string, or shell=true with a command that s a sequence of strings. these forms are accepted by the underlying subprocess.popen constructor but don t do what most users expect. also, added an explanation of quoting to the documentation.
column42: the submodules trio.ssl and trio.subprocess are now deprecated. their nontrivial contents have been moved to the main trio namespace. for the numerous constants, exceptions, and other helpers that were previously reexported from the standard ssl and subprocess modules, you should now use those modules directly.
column43: simplified nurseries: in trio, the rule used to be that parenting is a full time job , meaning that after a task opened a nursery and spawned some children into it, it had to immediately block in __aexit__ to supervise the new children, or else exception propagation wouldn t work. also there was some elaborate machinery to let you replace this supervision logic with your own custom supervision logic. thanks to new advances in task-rearing technology, parenting is no longer a full time job! now the supervision happens automatically in the background, and essentially the body of a async with trio.open_nursery block acts just like a task running inside the nursery. this is important: it makes it possible for libraries to abstract over nursery creation. for example, if you have a websocket library that needs to run a background task to handle websocket pings, you can now do that with async with open_websocket as ws: ..., and that can run a task in the background without your users having to worry about parenting it. and don t worry, you can still make custom supervisors; it turned out all that spiffy machinery was actually redundant and didn t provide much value.
column44: give up on trying to have different low-level waiting apis on unix and windows. all platforms now have trio.hazmat.wait_readable, trio.hazmat.wait_writable, and trio.hazmat.notify_closing. the old platform-specific synonyms wait_socket_*, notify_socket_closing, and notify_fd_closing have been deprecated.
column45: tasks spawned with nursery.start aren t treated as direct children of their nursery until they call task_status.started. this is visible through the task tree introspection attributes such as task.parent_nursery. sometimes, though, you want to know where the task is going to wind up, even if it hasn t finished initializing yet. to support this, we added a new attribute task.eventual_parent_nursery. for a task spawned with start that hasn t yet called started, this is the nursery that the task was nominally started in, where it will be running once it finishes starting up. in all other cases, it is none.
column46: trio.testing.wait_all_tasks_blocked now takes a tiebreaker= argument. the main use is to allow mockclock's auto-jump functionality to avoid interfering with direct use of wait_all_tasks_blocked in the same test.
column47: trio socket methods like bind and connect no longer require pre-resolved numeric addresses; you can now pass regular hostnames and trio will implicitly resolve them for you.
column48: trio.queue and trio.hazmat.unboundedqueue have been deprecated, in favor of trio.open_memory_channel.
column49: as was foretold in the v0.2.0 release notes, the bind method on trio sockets is now async. please update your calls or better yet switch to our shiny new high-level networking api, like serve_tcp.
column50: we no longer use runtime code generation to dispatch core functions like current_time. static analysis tools like mypy and pylint should now be able to recognize and analyze all of trio s top-level functions .
column51: remove clear method on trio.event: it was deprecated in 0.12.0.
column52: new support for tests to cleanly hook hostname lookup and socket operations: see virtual networking for testing. in addition, trio.socket.sockettype is now an empty abstract base class, with the actual socket class made private. this shouldn t effect anyone, since the only thing you could directly use it for in the first place was isinstance checks, and those still work
column53: remove the apis deprecated in 0.5.0.
column54: you can now create an unbounded capacitylimiter by initializing with math.inf
column55: added an internal mechanism for pytest-trio s hypothesis integration to make the task scheduler reproducible and avoid flaky tests.
column56: the iteration of the blocking generators produced by pathlib was performed in the trio thread. with this fix, the previous behavior is restored: the blocking generators are converted into lists in a thread dedicated to blocking io calls.
column57: design and internals
column58: destructor methods are now protected against keyboardinterrupt.
column59: if you want to use trio, but are stuck with some other event loop like qt or pygame, then good news: now you can have both. for details, see: using guest mode to run trio on top of other event loops.

column77: remove trio.open_cancel_scope which was deprecated in 0.11.0.
column78: remove the deprecated trio.ssl and trio.subprocess modules.
column79: trio.from_thread.run no longer crashes the trio run if it is executed after the system nursery has been closed but before the run has finished. calls made at this time will now raise trio.runfinishederror. this fixes a regression introduced in trio 0.17.0. the window in question is only one scheduler tick long in most cases, but may be longer if async generators need to be cleaned up.
column80: the test suite now passes with openssl v1.1.1. unfortunately this required temporarily disabling tls v1.3 during tests; see openssl bugs #7948 and #7967. we believe tls v1.3 should work in most real use cases, but will be monitoring the situation.
column81: trio now uses signal.set_wakeup_fd on all platforms. this is mostly an internal refactoring with no user-visible effect, but in theory it should fix a few extremely-rare race conditions on unix that could have caused signal delivery to be delayed.
column82: the plumbing of trio s cancellation system has been substantially overhauled to improve performance and ease future planned improvements. notably, there is no longer any internal concept of a cancel stack , and checkpoints now take constant time regardless of the cancel scope nesting depth.
column83: trio.cancelled exceptions now always propagate until they reach the outermost unshielded cancelled scope, even if more cancellations occur or shielding is changed between when the cancelled is delivered and when it is caught.
column84: and in case you have some exotic use case where you need to spawn threads manually, but want to take advantage of trio s cache, you can do that using the new trio.lowlevel.start_thread_soon.
column85: if you want to create a trio.process object, you now have to call trio.open_process; calling trio.process directly was deprecated in v0.12.0 and has now been removed.
column86: when a trio task makes improper use of a non-trio async library, trio now causes an exception to be raised within the task at the point of the error, rather than abandoning the task and raising an error in its parent. this improves debuggability and resolves the triointernalerror that would sometimes result from the old strategy.
column87: when a socket sendall call was cancelled, it used to attach some metadata to the exception reporting how much data was actually sent. it no longer does this, because in common configurations like an sslstream wrapped around a socketstream it becomes ambiguous which level the partial metadata applies to, leading to confusion and bugs. there is no longer any way to tell how much data was sent after a sendall is cancelled.
column88: there are also some classes that were explicitly designed to be subclassed, like the ones in trio.abc. subclassing these is still supported. however, for all other classes, attempts to subclass will now raise a deprecation warning, and in the future will raise an error.
column89: entering a cancel scope whose deadline is in the past now immediately cancels it, so cancelled will be raised by the first checkpoint in the cancel scope rather than the second one. this also affects constructs like with trio.move_on_after:.
column90: if this causes problems for you, feel free to drop by our chat room or file a bug, to discuss alternatives or make a case for why some particular class should be designed to support subclassing.
column91: the hazmat function current_call_soon_thread_and_signal_safe is being replaced by trio.hazmat.triotoken
column92: fixed the hash behavior of trio.path to match pathlib.path. previously trio.path s hash was inherited from object instead of from pathlib.purepath. thus, hashing two trio.path's or a trio.path and a pathlib.path with the same underlying path would yield different results.
column93: trio is a young and ambitious project, but it also aims to become a stable, production-quality foundation for async i/o in python. therefore, our approach for now is to provide deprecation warnings where-ever possible, but on a fairly aggressive cycle as we push towards stability. if you use trio you should read and subscribe to issue #1. we d also welcome feedback on how this approach is working, whether our deprecation warnings could be more helpful, or anything else.
column94: trio now consistently uses run for functions that take and run an async function !), and run_sync for functions that take and run a synchronous function. as part of this:
column95: it is now possible to take weakrefs to lock and many other classes
column96: it turns out that everyone got confused by the name trio.hazmat. so that name has been deprecated, and the new name is trio.lowlevel.
column97: use slots for memory channel state and statistics which should make memory channels slightly smaller and faster.
column98: trio now gives a reasonable traceback and error message in most cases when its invariants surrounding cancel scope nesting have been violated. the previous behavior was an inscrutable chain of triointernalerrors.
column99: trio.catch_signals has been deprecated in favor of open_signal_receiver. the main differences are: it takes *-args now to specify the list of signals instead of catch_signals), and, the async iterator now yields individual signals, instead of batches
column100: a bug related to the following methods has been introduced in version 0.12.0:
column101: the trio.process.returncode attribute is now automatically updated as needed, instead of only when you call poll or wait. also, repr now always contains up-to-date information about the process status.
column102: calling open_signal_receiver with no arguments used to succeed without listening for any signals. this was confusing, so now it raises typeerror instead.
column103: use slots for task which should make them slightly smaller and faster.
column104: run_sync_in_worker_thread now has a robust mechanism for applying capacity limits to the number of concurrent threads
column105: on linux kernels v5.3 or newer, trio.process.wait now uses the pidfd api to track child processes. this shouldn t have any user-visible change, but it makes working with subprocesses faster and use less memory.
column106: trio now uses yapf to standardize formatting across the source tree, so we never have to think about whitespace again.
column107: added a new abstract api for byte streams, and trio.testing gained helpers for creating fake streams for testing your protocol implementation and checking that your custom stream implementation follows the stream contract.
column108: contributing to trio and related projects
column109: breaking changes and deprecations
column110: any attempt to inherit from cancelscope or nursery now raises typeerror. also exposed as public classes for type-checking, etc.
column111: sendchannel, receivechannel, listener, and open_memory_channel can now be referenced using a generic type parameter using pep 484 syntax: trio.abc.sendchannel, trio.abc.listener, trio.open_memory_channel, etc. the added type information does not change the runtime semantics, but permits better integration with external static type checkers.
column112: built with sphinx using a theme provided by read the docs.
column113: if you re using trio.hazmat.wait_task_rescheduled and other low-level routines to implement a new sleeping primitive, you can now use the new trio.hazmat.task.custom_sleep_data attribute to pass arbitrary data between the sleeping task, abort function, and waking task.
column114: prevent crashes when used with sentry .
column115: prevent crashes when used with sentry .
column116: stop allowing subclassing public classes. this behavior was deprecated in 0.15.0.
column117: the length of typical exception traces coming from trio has been greatly reduced. this was done by eliminating many of the exception frames related to details of the implementation. for examples, see the blog post.
column118: trio.socket.sendall is deprecated; use trio.open_tcp_stream and socketstream.send_all instead
column119: trio.hazmat.result, trio.hazmat.value and trio.hazmat.error have been replaced by the equivalent classes in the outcome library.
column120: added a helpful error message if an async function is passed to trio.from_thread.run_sync or a sync function to trio.from_thread.run.
column121: this also lets us move a number of lower-level features out of the main trio namespace and into trio.hazmat:
column122: pycharm can now offer better completions for the trio and trio.hazmat modules
column123: tasks created by spawn_system_task now no longer inherit the creator s contextvars context, instead using one created at run.
column124: we refactored trio.testing.mockclock so that it no longer needs to run an internal task to manage autojumping. this should be mostly invisible to users, but there is one semantic change: the interaction between trio.testing.wait_all_tasks_blocked and the autojump clock was fixed. now, the autojump will always wait until after all wait_all_tasks_blocked calls have finished before firing, instead of it depending on which threshold values you passed.
column125: the trio.socket.getprotobyname function is now async, like it should have been all along. i doubt anyone will ever use it, but that s no reason not to get the details right.
column126: an exception encapsulated within a multierror doesn t need to be hashable anymore.
column127: added a helpful error message if an async function is passed to trio.to_thread.run_sync.
column128: if you re using trio s low-level interfaces like trio.hazmat.wait_readable or similar, and then you close a socket or file descriptor, you re supposed to call trio.hazmat.notify_closing first so trio can clean up properly. but what if you forget? in the past, trio would tend to either deadlock or explode spectacularly. now, it s much more robust to this situation, and should generally survive.
column129: trio now supports automatic async generator finalization, so more async generators will work even if you don t wrap them in async with async_generator.aclosing: blocks. please see the documentation for important caveats; in particular, yielding within a nursery or cancel scope remains unsupported.
column130: reworked trio, trio.testing, and trio.socket namespace construction, making them more understandable by static analysis tools. this should improve tab completion in editors, reduce false positives from pylint, and is a first step towards providing type hints.
column131: change the default timeout in trio.open_tcp_stream to 0.250 seconds, for consistency with rfc 8305.
column132: it was decided that 0.1.0 s yield point terminology was confusing; we now use checkpoint instead. as part of this, the following functions in trio.hazmat are changing names:
column133: upcoming breaking changes with warnings :
column134: remove wait_socket_*, notify_socket_closing, notify_fd_closing, run_sync_in_worker_thread and current_default_worker_thread_limiter. they were deprecated in 0.12.0.
column135: fix a crash that could happen when using mockclock with autojump enabled and a non-zero rate.
column136: updates the formatting of exception messages raised by trio.open_tcp_stream to correctly handle a hostname passed in as bytes, by converting the hostname to a string.
column137: make event more lightweight by using less objects and simpler structures . this may benefit applications that create a large number of event instances, such as with the replace event object on every set idiom.
column138: fix a memory leak in trio.capacitylimiter, that could occur when acquire or acquire_on_behalf_of was cancelled.
column139: however, this is somewhat experimental, so if you use windows then please keep an eye out and let us know if you run into any problems!
column140: remove the deprecated tiebreaker argument to trio.testing.wait_all_tasks_blocked.
column141: we ve added freebsd to the list of platforms we support and test on.
column142: some version of macos have a buggy getaddrinfo that was causing spurious test failures; we now detect those systems and skip the relevant test when found.
column143: there are a number of methods on trio.ssl.sslstream that report information about the negotiated tls connection, like selected_alpn_protocol, and thus cannot succeed until after the handshake has been performed. previously, we returned none from these methods, like the stdlib ssl module does, but this is confusing, because that can also be a valid return value. now we raise trio.ssl.needhandshakeerror instead.
column144: fixed some corner cases in trio socket method implicit name resolution to better match stdlib behavior. example: sock.bind) now binds to the wildcard address instead of raising an error.
column145: fixed a race condition on macos, where trio s tcp listener would crash if an incoming tcp connection was closed before the listener had a chance to accept it.
column146: previously, when trio.run_process was cancelled, it always killed the subprocess immediately. now, on unix, it first gives the process a chance to clean up by sending sigterm, and only escalates to sigkill if the process is still running after 5 seconds. but if you prefer the old behavior, or want to adjust the timeout, then don t worry: you can now pass a custom deliver_cancel= argument to define your own process killing policy.
column147: on windows, trio now works around the buggy behavior of certain layered service providers that are built on top of a commercially available library called komodia redirector. this benefits users of products such as astrill vpn and qustodio parental controls. previously, trio would crash on startup when run on a system where such a product was installed.
column148: initial subprocess support. add trio.subprocess.process, an async wrapper around the stdlib subprocess.popen class, which permits spawning subprocesses and communicating with them over standard trio streams. trio.subprocess also reexports all the stdlib subprocess exceptions and constants for convenience.
column149: on ubuntu systems, the system python includes a custom unhandled-exception hook to perform crash reporting. unfortunately, trio wants to use the same hook to print nice multierror tracebacks, causing a conflict. previously, trio would detect the conflict, print a warning, and you just wouldn t get nice multierror tracebacks. now, trio has gotten clever enough to integrate its hook with ubuntu s, so the two systems should just work together.
column150: new and improved signal catching api: open_signal_receiver.
column151: simplified the windows subprocess pipe send_all code, and in the process fixed a theoretical bug where closing a pipe at just the wrong time could produce errors or cause data to be redirected to the wrong pipe.
column152: deprecations and removals
column153: deprecations and removals
column154: deprecations and removals
column155: deprecations and removals
column156: deprecations and removals
column157: deprecations and removals
column158: deprecations and removals
column159: deprecations and removals
column160: deprecations and removals
column161: deprecations and removals
column162: deprecations and removals
column163: deprecations and removals
column164: deprecations and removals
column165: deprecations and removals
column166: it turns out that creating a subprocess can block the parent process for a surprisingly long time. so trio.open_process now uses a worker thread to avoid blocking the event loop.
column167: trio now reliably detects if you accidentally do something like this, and gives a helpful error message.
column168: add support for unbound cancel scopes : you can now construct a trio.cancelscope without entering its context, e.g., so you can pass it to another task which will use it to wrap some work that you want to be able to cancel from afar.
column169: the low level trio.hazmat.wait_socket_readable, wait_socket_writable, and notify_socket_close now work on bare socket descriptors, instead of requiring a socket.socket object.
column170: calling str on a trio.cancelled exception object returns cancelled instead of an empty string.
column171: the event loop now holds on to references of coroutine frames for only the minimum necessary period of time.
column172: the resolve_local_address and resolve_remote_address methods on trio sockets have been deprecated; these are unnecessary now that you can just pass your hostnames directly to the socket methods you want to use.
column173: we took the opportunity to refactor run_in_trio_thread and await_in_trio_thread into the new class trio.blockingtrioportal
column174: the trio.path classmethods, home and cwd, are now async functions. previously, a bug in the forwarding logic meant cwd was synchronous and home didn t work at all.
